questions.text: The level of the posterior superior iliac spine is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: S2
 
  • The posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS) is a bony landmark located on the posterior aspect of the iliac bone, which is one of the bones that make up the pelvis.
  • It is used as a reference point in anatomical and medical assessments.
  • The PSIS is found at the level of the second sacral vertebra (S2). It is situated slightly above the gluteal fold on each side of the lower back.

 



Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page No 748, 978

questions.text: The axillary artery is split into three sections by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option 2:Pectoralis Minor
  • The axillary artery is split into three sections by the pectoralis minor muscle.
  • The three sections are:
1- First part: Superior to the pectoralis minor muscle.
2-Second part: Below the pectoralis minor muscle, but still anterior to the subscapularis muscle.
3-Third part: Below the subscapularis muscle, and posterior to the teres major muscle.
 
  • The pectoralis minor muscle is a small triangular muscle that lies in the anterior axilla.
  •  It originates from the third, fourth, and fifth ribs, and inserts onto the coracoid process of the scapula.
  • The pectoralis minor muscle helps to stabilize the shoulder joint and to move the arm forward.



Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 1464.e87

questions.text: Which of the following are transversely oriented canals that offer a radial blood flow path?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  Volkmann's canal
 

  • Volkmann's canals, also known as perforating canals, are small channels in bone tissue.
  • They run transversely (horizontally) to the long axis of the bone.
  • Volkmann's canals connect the Haversian canals within the Haversian systems (osteons) of compact bone.
  • Their primary function is to provide a radial blood flow path from the periosteum (outer surface) to the endosteum (inner surface) of the bone.
  • This radial arrangement ensures efficient vascular supply and communication between different parts of the bone.
  • It allows blood vessels, nerves, and connective tissue to traverse through the bone for nourishment and support.

Reference : Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,41st Edition - page no.89

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the characteristics of lamellar bone?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Haversian system
 

  • Lamellar bone is a type of bone tissue that is characterized by the presence of Haversian systems. Haversian systems are cylindrical structures that are made up of concentric layers of lamellae, which are thin sheets of bone tissue.
  • The Haversian system is a fundamental unit of compact bone that provides strength and support to the bone.
  • The lamellae are arranged in a regular pattern, and they are surrounded by a central canal that contains blood vessels and nerves.
  • Lamellar bone is the most common type of bone tissue in the adult skeleton.
  • It is found in the outer layer of cortical bone, as well as in the trabecular bone that makes up the inner part of some bones.

Reference : Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,41st Edition - page no.88

questions.text: The number of intrinsic hand muscles that the ulnar nerve supplies is:
questions.solution:
Four muscle groups comprise the intrinsic hand. These are the thenar, hypothenar, interossei and the lumbrical muscles. Amongst these ulnar nerve supplies

A. Hypothenar Muscles (3+1* muscles)
1. Abductor digiti minimi (ADM)
2. Flexor digiti minimi brevis (FDMB)
3. Opponens digiti minimi (ODM)

Also supplies - Palmaris brevis (superficial to Hypothenar muscles)

B. Interossei (8 muscles)
1.Dorsal interossei (4 muscles)
2. Palmar interossei (4muscles)

C. Lumbricals (2 muscles)
3rd and 4th Lumbrical is supplied by Ulnar nerve

D. Thenar muscles (1 muscle)
Adductor pollicis 

Adding up all these intrinsic hand muscles supplied by the ulnar nerve, we get a total of 4+8+2+1+1+ =15 muscles.

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 984

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Haldane Effect is not true?
questions.solution:
The correct option is 2:Binding of Oxygen to Hb makes it more acidic.
The Haldane Effect describes the phenomenon where the binding of oxygen to hemoglobin (Hb) in the lungs promotes the release of carbon dioxide (CO2) from the blood into the lungs, while the release of oxygen from Hb in the tissues promotes the uptake of CO2 from the tissues into the blood.
This effect is due to the fact that oxygenated Hb has a lower affinity for CO2 and protons than deoxygenated Hb.
Option 2 is false because the binding of oxygen to Hb actually makes it less acidic, not more acidic. When oxygen binds to Hb, it forms oxyhemoglobin (HbO2), which is a stronger acid acceptor than deoxygenated Hb. This means that HbO2 can buffer excess protons in the blood, which reduces the acidity of the blood.

Option 4 is true because :A decrease in blood pH, which indicates an increase in acidity, actually results in a decrease affinity of Hb for oxygen.This is known as the Bohr Effect, which describes how the binding of protons (H+) to Hb in the tissues promotes the release of oxygen from Hb to the tissues. 

Option 1 is true because the binding of oxygen to Hb reduces its affinity for CO2, as mentioned above.

Option 3 is true because deoxygenated Hb has a higher affinity for protons than oxygenated Hb, so it binds more H+ ions in the tissues.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 631,632

questions.text: Which of the following effects is governed by the Gibbs-Donnan effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Chloride shift
 
  • HCO3-/Cl- transporter is present on the RBC membrane. It allows the bicarbonate ions to diffuse out of the RBC into the plasma and in exchange the chloride ions diffuse into the RBC via facilitated diffusion counter transport. This is known as HAMBURGER PHENOMENON OR CHLORIDE SHIFT.
  • The Chloride Shift is governed by the Gibbs–Donnan effect  which describes the behaviour of charged particles across a semipermeable membrane.   
  • The Gibbs–Donnan theory describes the equilibrium conditions for ions separated by a  semipermeable  membrane when  the presence of non permeating particles ( like Proteins ) distorts the distribution of permeating ions on the two sides of the semi permeable membrane.
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 8,9

questions.text: Which section of the renal tubule reabsorbs the most water when there are high levels of ADH present?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Proximal tubule
 
  • Vasopressin or Anti Diuretic Hormone is secreted by Hypothalamus and is stored in Posterior Pituitary.
  • It is released from Posterior Pituitary in response to increase in plasma osmolarity and decrease in blood volume.
  • It acts on V2 receptors present in the Principal cells of the Collecting Ducts which leads to increased insertion of Aquaporin receptors. This leads to water reabsorption
  • However though ADH mainly acts on the Collecting Ducts still maximum reabsorption occurs in the Proximal Convoluted Tubule
  • Option 1, Proximal Tubule, is correct. When there are high levels of ADH (Antidiuretic hormone) present, the permeability of the walls of the collecting ducts and distal convoluted tubules to water increases.
  • However, the majority of water reabsorption occurs in the proximal tubule, which is the first segment of the renal tubule.
  • The proximal tubule is responsible for reabsorbing approximately 65% of the filtered water, along with ions, glucose, amino acids, and other solutes.
  • This occurs through both active and passive transport mechanisms, including the use of transport proteins and ion channels.
  • Therefore, in the presence of high levels of ADH, the proximal tubule would still be responsible for reabsorbing the majority of the filtered water, even though the collecting ducts and distal convoluted tubules have become more permeable to water.
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 673

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Bohr effect is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Binding of Oxygen to Hb promotes release of CO2

BOHR EFFECT :-
The increase in the level of Carbon Dioxide caused by tissue metabolism leads to the rightward shift of the OXYGEN HAEMOGLOBIN DISSOCIATION CURVE and this is known as the BOHR EFFECT.
Right shift of the curve denotes the fact that the affinity of haemoglobin towards oxygen decreases à Increased oxygen unloading occurs at the tissues
CAUSES OF RIGHT SHIFT :-
•     Exercise
•     Decreased pH / Increased H+
•     Increased temperature
•     Hypoxia
•     Increased 2,3-BPG
•     Increased CO2

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 631

In Central diabetes Insipidus there is deficiency of Anti Diuretic Hormone. This decreases the water reabsorption in the collecting ducts, thereby decreasing the tubular fluid osmolarity in the collecting ducts.

questions.text: What is the reason of the dicrotic notch on the aortic pressure curve?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Closure of the aortic valve
  • The Dicrotic Notch occurs due to pressure changes caused by the closure of the Aortic Valve.
  •  The aortic valve opens during systole to allow blood to be ejected from the left ventricle into the aorta.
  • Once the left ventricle has finished contracting, the pressure in the aorta begins to fall as blood flows out into the systemic circulation.
  • As the pressure in the aorta falls, the aortic valve begins to close, causing a brief increase in pressure known as the dicrotic notch.
  • This notch is followed by a second, smaller rise in pressure as the aortic valve closes completely, preventing blood from flowing back into the left ventricle.
  • he closure of the aortic valve is essential for maintaining forward blood flow and preventing backflow into the left ventricle.


 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 529

questions.text: The greatest absorption of short-chain fatty acids generated by bacteria occurs in the:

  •  Fermentation results in production of multiple groups of metabolites of which short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) are the major  metabolic by products.
  • Examples of short-chain fatty acids (SCFA) includes-

    • BUTYRATE

  Maximum absorption of metabolites-  Jejunum > ileum > colon > duodenum except : 
1. Vit B12 & Bile salt - Terminal Ileum
2. SCFA - colon
3. Iron and folate - duodenum

questions.text: Regardless of the GFR value, a fixed portion of the filtered load is absorbed in the proximal tubule. What causes this?
questions.solution:
The correct option for the given question is 1. Tubuloglomerular feedback.
  • Tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF) is a mechanism that regulates the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) by controlling the diameter of the afferent arteriole. The TGF mechanism involves the detection of changes in sodium chloride concentration in the macula densa cells of the juxtaglomerular apparatus (JGA) located in the distal convoluted tubule.
  • When the GFR increases, the flow of filtrate through the tubules also increases, and the concentration of sodium chloride in the macula densa cells increases. This triggers the release of vasoconstrictor chemicals, such as adenosine and thromboxane, which constrict the afferent arteriole, reducing the GFR.
  • Conversely, when the GFR decreases, the concentration of sodium chloride in the macula densa cells decreases, and this triggers the release of vasodilator chemicals, such as nitric oxide, which dilate the afferent arteriole, increasing the GFR.
  • However, regardless of the GFR value, a fixed portion of the filtered load is absorbed in the proximal tubule. This is due to the fact that the proximal tubule has a high capacity for reabsorption and can reabsorb up to 65% of the filtered load. 
     

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 672

questions.text: Which of the following conditions falls under the category of gastrointestinal neurocrine?

They do not fall under the category of gastrointestinal neurocrine. GIP stimulates insulin release in response to food intake, Peptide YY regulates appetite and inhibits gastric emptying, and Somatostatin inhibits the release of other gastrointestinal hormones.
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 449

questions.text: What is the Warburg effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Aerobic glycolysis
The Warburg Effect refers to the phenomenon where cancer cells preferentially use glycolysis for energy production even in the presence of oxygen (aerobic conditions). Hence, this is called as aerobic glycolysis. (versus when cell normally uses glycolysis for ATP in absence of oxygen i.e anaerobic conditions)

Key Features of Warburg Effect
  • Cancer cells rely on glycolysis → Convert glucose to lactate, even when oxygen is available.
  • Less ATP per glucose molecule (compared to oxidative phosphorylation), but faster ATP production.
  • Increased glucose uptake (basis for PET scans using FDG in cancer detection)
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 704.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is most likely to cluster on the surface of a globular protein in the plasma?

Examples of non-polar amino acids

  • Aromatic amino acids-Phenylalanine, tyrosine, tryptophan ( not histidine )
  • Sulfur containing amino acids-Methionine
  • Alanie
  • Proline
Rest of the amino acids constitute polar group.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews Biochemistry, 5th edition, Page no 2.

questions.text: The steroid nucleus of bile acids is conjugated to which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
Option 1 which states that the steroid nucleus of bile acids is conjugated to glycine and taurine is the correct option.
  • The steroid nucleus of bile acids is conjugated to the amino acids glycine and taurine.
  • Bile acids are synthesized from cholesterol in the liver and secreted into the small intestine to aid in the digestion and absorption of dietary fats.
  • The steroid nucleus of bile acids consists of four fused rings, and the molecule also contains a hydroxyl group and a carboxylic acid group.
  • In the liver, bile acids are conjugated with either glycine or taurine to form glycine conjugated bile acids or taurine conjugated bile acids, respectively.
  • Conjugation with these amino acids increases the water solubility of the bile acids, which facilitates their excretion in the urine and prevents their accumulation in the body. 
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 265.

questions.text: The template DNA strand has the following sequence: 5'-GATATC -3'. What RNA sequence will be produced?
questions.solution:
The correct option is 2.
  • The RNA sequence produced from the given DNA template strand is 5'-GAUAUC-3'.
  • This is because RNA is synthesized by complementary base pairing with the template DNA strand, using the rules of base pairing (A with U and G with C).
  • So, for the given DNA sequence 5'-GATATC-3', the RNA sequence produced would be 5'-GAUAUC-3', where T in DNA is replaced by U in RNA. 
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 349.

questions.text: What do UGA codons indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Termination of protein synthesis

Examples of stop codons which result in termination of protein synthesis-
  • UGA (Opal)
  • UAG (Ambre)
  • UAA (Ochre)
Note- UGA codes for selenocysteine whereas UAG codes for pyrolysine in prokaryotes.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 414.

questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Denaturation→Annealing→Extension

choices.text: Caused by mutation in HPRT gene on chromosome 6

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Caused by mutation in HPRT gene on chromosome 6

Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome is an X linked recessive disorder which occurs due to deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyl transferase ( HGPRT )
HGPRT is responsible for generation of purine nucleotides such as IMP/GMP from bases such as hypoxanthine/guanine via purine salvage pathway.
As a result, purines accumulate resulting in increased degradation and generation of uric acid leading to hyperuricemia.

Clinically manifests as-
  • Self mutilation
  • Aggression
  • Intellectual disability
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Gout
Remember- Partial deficiency of HGPRTase results in Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 344.

questions.text: What is linked to a homogentisic acid oxidase deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Alkaptonuria

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder which occurs due to deficiency of enzyme homogentisate oxidase causing impaired conversion of homogentisate to malylacetic acid.
The accumulated homogentisate gets converted to benzoquinone which then polymerizes to form alkapton bodies.
These alkapton bodies cause black discoloration of urine on long standing.
Clinical features-
  • Blac/reddish discoloration of diaper in infants with absent mental retardation.
  • Back pain, pigmentation and ochronosis in adults.
Alkaptonuria along with cystinnuria, albinism and essential pentosuria constitute Garrod’s tetrad.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 296.

questions.text: For total iron deficiency, what is the Canzoni formula?
Which of the following Tyrosine Receptor Kinases is affected by Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: TRK B
 
  • TRK receptors are a family of tyrosine kinases.
  • Each of these receptor types has different binding affinity to certain types of neurotrophins. The different signals initiated by the 3 types of receptors are important for generating diverse biological responses.
  • The three most common types of  TRK  Receptors are  TRK A, TRK B, TRK C.





Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK538532/

questions.text: What is an example of Acute Pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2): Fat Necrosis
 
  • Acute pancreatitis is an inflammatory condition of the pancreas characterized by autodigestion of pancreatic tissue.
  • Fat necrosis is a characteristic feature of acute pancreatitis, where pancreatic enzymes cause damage to adipose tissue, leading to the release of fatty acids and formation of calcium soaps( saponification). 
* Other options:
  • Liquefactive necrosis is a type of necrosis characterized by the formation of a liquid, viscous mass in the affected tissue, commonly seen in conditions such as abscesses or brain infarction.
  • Fibrinoid necrosis is a type of necrosis associated with immune-mediated reactions and is typically observed in blood vessels in conditions such as vasculitis.
  • In Coagulative necrosis, the architectural structure of the tissue is preserved, but the cells undergo irreversible injury and denaturation.
* [Extra Edge]: Type of Necrosis



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 41.

questions.text: What are the secondary morphogenetic errors that result from the destruction of an organ that was formerly developing normally?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2): Disruption
 
  • Secondary morphogenetic errors are abnormalities that occur during organ development due to external factors disrupting normal developmental processes.
  • Disruption refers to the destruction or damage of a previously developing organ or structure, leading to the formation of secondary abnormalities.
* Other options:
  • Malformation refers to primary errors in organ development that occur during embryogenesis and result in structural abnormalities.
  • Deformation refers to abnormalities in organ shape or structure due to mechanical forces acting on a developing organ.
  • Association refers to a non-random occurrence of multiple anomalies that are not causally related but often coexist in the same individual.
* [Extra Edge]: General pathology terms with definitions



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 47.

questions.text: What is the term for differentiating the expression of a gene based on the parent of origin?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Genomic imprinting
 
  • MOSAICISM – Presence of genetically distinct cell lines in the same individual
(Example – McCune Albright syndrome )
  • ANTICIPATION – Increased severity or earlier onset of disease in succeeding generations ( Example – Trinucleotide Repeat disorders )
  • NONPENETRANCE- It means that not all individuals with the disease shows the disease due to incomplete or non penetrance.

GENOMIC IMPRINTING :-
  • In this one gene copy is silenced by methylation while the other copy is expressed based on parent of origin.
  • Examples :- PRADER WILLI SYNDROME , ANGELMAN SYNDROME
 


[TRICK –
PRADER WILLI SYNDROME – PAPA KA BETA- PATERNAL GENE DELETED -Spoiled brat—only eats thus obese
ANGELMAN SYNDROME – ANGEL- MEANS MOTHER- MATERNAL GENE DELETED ]



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 634

questions.text: Which of the following statements about irreversible cell injury is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Cytoplasmic vacuolization
 
  • Irreversible cell injury refers to cellular damage that is beyond the point of recovery and leads to cell death.
  • Cytoplasmic vacuolization is a characteristic feature of reversible cell injury, not irreversible cell injury.
  • Clumping of nuclear chromatin, lysosomal rupture, and degradation of membrane phospholipids are all features of irreversible cell injury.
  • During irreversible cell injury, the cells undergo extensive damage to various cellular components, leading to loss of cell membrane integrity, organelle dysfunction, and ultimately cell death.
* [Extra Edge]: Reversible Vs Irreversible Cell Injury



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 39.

questions.text: Except for __________, all of the following carry out cellular and flagella motions.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Intermediate filaments

THE FOLLOWING FLOWCHART IS BASED ON ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT TOPICS FREQUENTLY TESTED IN EXAMS :-



   



Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 38,39

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding apoptosis are true except ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Cellular swelling
 
  • Apoptosis is a programmed cell death process that plays a crucial role in maintaining tissue homeostasis and eliminating damaged or unwanted cells.
  • Cellular swelling is not a characteristic feature of apoptosis. It is more commonly observed in reversible cell injury or necrosis.
  • Nuclear compaction, intact cell membrane, and cytoplasmic eosinophilia are all features of apoptosis.
  • Apoptotic cells typically show nuclear condensation, membrane blebbing, and fragmentation into membrane-bound apoptotic bodies.
Apoptosis Vs Necrosis



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 43.

questions.text: Among the following, which has the most friable vegetation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Infective endocarditis
 
  • Friable vegetation refers to fragile and easily breakable growths on heart valves, commonly observed in infective endocarditis.
  • Infective endocarditis is a microbial infection of the endocardium, typically caused by bacteria.
  • The vegetations in infective endocarditis consist of fibrin, platelets, microorganisms, and inflammatory cells, and they can become large and friable.
* [Extra Edge]: Other options
  • Libman-Sacks endocarditis is a nonbacterial form of endocarditis associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), but the vegetations are usually small and non-friable.
  • Rheumatic heart disease is a consequence of rheumatic fever and can lead to valvular damage, but the vegetations are typically firm rather than friable.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 562.

questions.text: Apple Green birefringence in Amyloid is observed on:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Polarized light
 
  • The histologic diagnosis of amyloid is based almost entirely on its staining characteristics.
  • The most common staining technique uses the dye Congo red, which under ordinary light imparts a pink or red color to amyloid deposits. Under polarized light, the Congo red–stained amyloid shows so-called apple-green birefringence. 
  • This reaction is shared by all forms of amyloid and is caused by the cross-β-pleated configuration of amyloid fibrils.


Fig: Polarizing microscope image of amyloidosis

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 260.

questions.text: With the exception of, asbestosis exhibits all of the traits listed below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Emphysema
 
  • Asbestosis is a chronic lung disease caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibers.
  • It is characterized by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis and fibrous pleural thickening.
  • Calcific pleural plaques are also commonly seen in individuals with asbestosis.
  • However, emphysema is not typically associated with asbestosis.
  • Emphysema is a separate lung condition characterized by destruction of the alveolar walls, leading to abnormal enlargement of air spaces.
  • While both asbestosis and emphysema can occur concurrently in individuals with a history of asbestos exposure, they are distinct entities.
PNEUMOCONIOSIS:


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 695.

questions.text: Typically, pseudopolyps are seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Ulcerative colitis 
 
  • Pseudo polyps are inflammatory polypoid lesions that can be seen in the colon and rectum.
  • They are typically observed in the setting of chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal mucosa.
  • Ulcerative colitis, an inflammatory bowel disease, is one of the conditions in which pseudo polyps are commonly seen.
  • Pseudo polyps are formed due to the regeneration of the mucosal epithelium in areas of ulceration and destruction.
Crohn’s vs ulcerative colitis:



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 802.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about atypical pneumonia is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Alveolar exudates
 
  • Atypical pneumonia refers to pneumonia caused by organisms such as Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydophila pneumoniae, and Legionella pneumophila.
  • Unlike typical bacterial pneumonia, atypical pneumonia is characterized by a more insidious onset and a milder clinical course.
  • Lymphocytic infiltrate is a characteristic finding in atypical pneumonia.
  • Dry cough is also commonly observed in patients with atypical pneumonia.
  • Interstitial pattern on X-ray is another feature associated with atypical pneumonia.
  • The presence of alveolar exudates is not a characteristic feature of atypical pneumonia, but rather seen in typical bacterial pneumonia.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 710.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about red infarcts is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): End-Arterial occlusion
 
  • Red infarcts occur in organs with dual blood supply or in tissues with significant collateral circulation.
  • They are characterized by hemorrhage into the infarcted area, giving a red appearance.
  • Red infarcts can occur due to venous occlusion or reperfusion injury.
  • In end-arterial occlusion, such as in the heart or kidney, the infarcted area lacks collateral circulation and typically shows pale or white appearance (pale infarcts), not red.
  • Ill-defined margins are a characteristic feature of red infarcts.
* [Extra Edge]: Infarct Type




Fig: Red and white infarcts

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 133.

questions.text: All of the following are trinucleotide repeating disorders which occur in the non coding / intron regions except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Option (4): Huntington Disease 
 
  • Fragile X Syndrome, Friedrich Ataxia, and Myotonic Dystrophy are all genetic disorders caused by trinucleotide repeat expansions in non-coding regions of the respective genes.
  • However, Huntington Disease is characterized by a trinucleotide repeat expansion (CAG repeat) in the coding region of the huntingtin (HTT) gene.
  • This repeat expansion leads to the production of an abnormal huntington protein, which causes neuronal degeneration and the clinical manifestations of Huntington Disease.

Trinucleotide Repeat Disorder



Mnemonic:  All trinucleotide repeat diroders occur in non coding regions except SHEK- Spinocerebellar ataxia,Huntington which are Exon and K(C)oding

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1285.

questions.text: Reversible polarity loss accompanied by pleomorphism is observed in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2): Dysplasia
 
  • Dysplasia is a cellular adaptation characterized by reversible polarity loss, cellular pleomorphism (variations in size, shape, and staining characteristics), and abnormal cellular organization.
  • Dysplastic cells exhibit loss of uniformity, altered nuclear size and shape, increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, and disordered cellular arrangement.
* Other options:
  • Metaplasia refers to the reversible change in which one adult cell type is replaced by another adult cell type
  • Anaplasia is the loss of cellular differentiation and reversion to a more primitive, undifferentiated state.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 272.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about hypertrophic scars is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): Disorganized collagen
 
  • Hypertrophic scars are characterized by excessive deposition of collagen in the dermis, resulting in raised, thickened scars.
  • They are confined to the wound margins and do not extend beyond the boundaries of the original injury.
  • Hypertrophic scars are generally not associated with disorganized collagen, as the collagen fibers are densely packed and oriented parallel to the epidermis.
The other options, including being confined to wound margins, regressing spontaneously, and having infrequent recurrence, are true statements about hypertrophic scars.

* [Extra Edge]: Keloid Vs Hypertrophic Scars


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 110.

questions.text: Which statement regarding both MPO deficiency and Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): Hypochlorite is absent
 
  • Myeloperoxidase (MPO) deficiency and Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) are both disorders affecting neutrophil function.
  • In MPO deficiency, the enzyme MPO, which is responsible for generating hypochlorite (a potent antimicrobial agent), is absent or deficient.
  • In CGD, the defect lies in the NADPH oxidase system, which leads to impaired respiratory burst and reduced production of reactive oxygen species (including hypochlorite).
  • Therefore, the correct statement is that hypochlorite is absent in both MPO deficiency and CGD.
  • The other options, including the absence of NADPH oxidase and abnormal NBT (nitro blue tetrazolium) test, are specific to CGD.

* [Extra Edge]: Immunodeficiency Disorder



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 241.

questions.text: Identify the synonyms of the correctly matched cell?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Target Cells or Codocytes
 
  • Target cells, also known as codocytes, are red blood cells with a central area of hemoglobin surrounded by a ring of pallor and a thickened rim of hemoglobin.
  • They appear as a target or bullseye-shaped cell under the microscope.

* [Extra Edge]: Types of RBCs


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 428.

questions.text: What is the name of non-neoplastic organised salivary gland tissue in the middle ear?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2): Choristoma
 
  • Choristoma refers to the presence of normal tissue in an abnormal location.
  • In the middle ear, the presence of non-neoplastic organized salivary gland tissue is known as a choristoma.
  • It is believed to occur due to abnormal embryological development or displacement of tissue during embryogenesis.
  • Choristomas can occur in various locations throughout the body and can consist of different types of tissues.
  • In the context of the middle ear, the presence of salivary gland tissue is an example of a choristoma.
Memorizing trick:- 
Choristoma- Chori (Theft)- Normal tissue is stolen and kept in abnormal location- normal tissue abnormal location 
Hamartoma- Hamara( Ours)- Abnormal tissue at normal location 

* [Extra Edge]:



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 270.

questions.text: The pustular lesion's culture revealed hemolytic gram-positive cocci. One can make a tentative diagnosis of Group A streptococcal pyoderma by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Bacitracin sensitivity

Group A strep is beta haemolytic cocci which are sensitive to bacitracin. It is used to differentiate it from Group B strep which is bacitracin resistant.
Other options- Optochin sensitivity and bile solubility are used to differentiate alpha haemolytic streptococci.
All streptococci are catalase negative.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 218.

questions.text: What is the primary factor causing St. Anthony's Fire?
questions.solution:
Correct option 1:Streptococcus
Audio explanation of the above.

  • St. Anthony's Fire, also known as ergotism, is a disease caused by the consumption of grains contaminated with the fungus Claviceps purpurea.
  • This fungus produces toxins known as ergot alkaloids, which can cause a range of symptoms including hallucinations, convulsions, gangrene, and even death.
  • It is also caused by  Streptococcus pyogenes -Erysipelas
 Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 215.

questions.text: Which of the organisms is most frequently linked to breast abscesses?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Staphylococcus Aureus

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism indicated in breast abscesses. The second most common cause is coagulase-negative staphylococci.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 204.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about cutaneous anthrax is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct answer 4:Wool Sorter's Disease

Wool Sorter's Disease is a type of pulmonary anthrax 
Cutaneous anthrax is caused by Bacillus anthracis. Human anthrax presents in one of three ways:
1- Cutaneous anthrax( Hide porter's disease): Black eschar at the base, with a very prominent inflammatory ring around the eschar, is referred to as a malignant pustule.
2- Pulmonary anthrax( Wool sorter's disease): Hemorrhagic pneumonia.
3- Intestinal anthrax: Hemorrhagic diarrhea. It occurs mainly in primitive communities that eat the carcasses of animals dying of anthrax.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 250.

choices.text: Aspiration is an important mode of transmission.
Legionella antigens in the urine is the gold standard of diagnosis.
Legionnaires disease is also known as Pontiac fever.

questions.text: Which of the following assertions about Legionella pneumonia is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Legionella antigens in the urine is the gold standard of diagnosis

Other options- Inhalation is the most common mode of transmission.
Pontaic fever is a less severe form of the disease caused by the organism.
Person-to-person transmission is low.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 409.

questions.text: After five days of incubation, which of the following displays the characteristic "fried egg" appearance on agar media?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Mycoplasma pneumoniae

On incubation on solid agar at 37 C, small colonies grow embedded in the agar showing a typical ‘fried-egg’ appearance. This is seen in M.pneumoniae  colonies.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 393.

choices.text: Toxin A is more potent than Toxin B

questions.text: All of the following statements about the Pathogenesis of Clostridium difficile-associated pseudomembranous enterocolitis are correct except ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Toxin A is more potent than Toxin B

Toxin B being a cytotoxin is more potent than Toxin A. Toxin A is an enterotoxin that attaches to the gut receptors.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 270.

questions.text: What is the process by which DNA molecules inside a cell exchange genetic information by direct contact known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Conjugation
  • The process by which DNA molecules inside a cell exchange genetic information is known as recombination. Recombination can occur through several mechanisms, including transposition, transformation, conjugation, and duplication.
  • Conjugation is a process by which genetic material is transferred between bacterial cells through direct physical contact.Transposition refers to the movement of a DNA segment from one location to another within the genome.
  • This process can result in the insertion of new genetic material into a chromosome or the deletion of existing genetic material.
  • Transformation involves the uptake of foreign DNA by a cell, which can then be incorporated into the cell's genome through recombination.
  • This process involves the formation of a conjugation bridge between two cells, through which DNA can be transferred.
  • Duplication refers to the process of copying a segment of DNA, resulting in two identical copies of the genetic material. 
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 60.

questions.text: All of the following are linked to EBV except ?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option 4, MALT Lymphoma. EBV (Epstein-Barr virus) is a member of the herpesvirus family and is known to be associated with several types of cancers and diseases.
It is a common virus that infects most people at some point in their lives, usually causing mild symptoms or no symptoms at all.
Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) and Hodgkin's lymphoma are two types of cancers that have a strong association with EBV.
Infectious mononucleosis, also known as glandular fever, is a viral infection caused by EBV. MALT (Mucosa-Associated Lymphoid Tissue) lymphoma is a type of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma that arises from lymphocytes in mucosal tissues such as the stomach, intestines, or lungs.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 481.

questions.text: What is a Hepatitis C virus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Single-stranded Enveloped RNA virus 

Hepatitis C is a single-stranded enveloped RNA virus. It is enclosed within a core and surrounded by an envelope, carrying glycoprotein spikes.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 553.

questions.text: What is a marker for chronic persistent HBV infection?
questions.solution:
The marker for chronic persistent HBV infection is option (2) HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen).

The presence of HBsAg indicates active infection with the hepatitis B virus, and it can be present in chronic infections. 

Among the options, best answer is option (2).

 
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 550, 551, 552.

questions.text: Which one of the following infections is not linked to congenital defects?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Neisseria

Neisseria is rarely transmitted during pregnancy. Hence, it is not linked with any congenital defects.
The other three are well-known causes of congenital infections which are grouped under TORCH infections.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 559.

questions.text: The most common cause of zoonotic cutaneous leishmaniasis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: L. Major
  • L.Major is the most common cause of cutaneous leishmaniasis. This is followed by L.Tropica and L.Braziliens.
  • L.Donovan rarely causes cutaneous leishmaniasis.
  • Out of the options given, the most common cause of zoonotic cutaneous leishmaniasis is L. major, which is transmitted by the bite of infected sandflies that have fed on infected rodents such as gerbils and jirds. L. tropica and L. donovani cause other forms of leishmaniasis, while L. braziliensis is the most common cause of the mucocutaneous form of the disease.
Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 53.

questions.text: What causes visceral larval migrans?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Toxocara

Visceral larva migrans is caused by Toxocara canis. It usually affects children and is asymptomatic.

Other options- Loa Loa- Loiasis
Enterobius vermicularis- Enterobiasis (Pinworm infection)
Taenia- Intestinal taeniasis and cysticercosis

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 167.

choices.text: Produced catalase to negate effect of toxic oxygen radicals

questions.text: The strategy adopted by mycobacterium tuberculosis to avoid intracellular killing is:
questions.solution:
Mycobacterium tuberculosis survive inside the macrophages by the action of lipoarabinomannan (LAM) which impairs phagosome-lysosome fusion by inhibiting intracellular calcium and phosphatidylinositol 3-phospahte. If bacteria are successful in arresting phagosome-lysosome fusion, then they happily replicate inside the macrophages.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 355.

questions.text: Due to exposure to_______, farmer's lung develops.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Thermoactinomyces sacchari.
 
  • Farmer's lung is a hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by Thermoactinomyces sp. like Saccharopolyspora rectivirgula (formerly known as Micropolyspora faeni).
  • It occurs due to inhalation of moldy hay and grains causing an immunological reaction.
  • Bagassosis is an occupational lung disease caused by the inhalation of bagasse or sugarcane dust. A thermophilic actinomycete, Thermoactinomyces sacchari is the causative organism. The symptoms are breathlessness, cough, hemoptysis, and fever. Initially, it can result in acute diffuse bronchiolitis. If left untreated it can progress to diffuse fibrosis, emphysema, and bronchiectasis.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 934.

questions.text: Which one of the aforementioned Fifth Generation Cephalosporins is active against MRSA?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Ceftaroline
 
  • Ceftaroline is a fifth-generation cephalosporin antibiotic that exhibits activity against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) bacteria.
  • It possesses a unique mechanism of action, targeting penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) that are involved in cell wall synthesis.
  • The spectrum of activity of ceftaroline includes not only MRSA but also other gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 779.

questions.text: Which biological agent for rheumatoid arthritis is a JAK inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Tofacitinib
 
  • Tofacitinib is a novel, oral JAK inhibitor which will inhibit the JAK-STAT pathway responsible for the production of cytokines and chemokines.
  • It is a new synthetic drug approved for severe cases of RA that are not responding to Methotrexate. Tofacitinib can be used alone or concurrently with Methotrexate, but should not be combined with azathioprine, cyclosporine or biological DMARDs.
  • It has been approved for the treatment of psoriatic arthritis and is also used in rheumatoid arthritis and ulcerative colitis.
Option 1 Etanercept is a recombinant fusion protein of TNF-receptor with Fc portion of human IgG1. It binds to and prevents TNFα from activating TNF receptors on the membrane of T-cells/macrophages.
Option 2 Tocilizumab, an IL-6 receptor antagonist, is FDA-approved for treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis, giant cell arteritis, polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis, and cytokine release syndrome.
Option 3 Abatacept is a recombinant fusion protein which combines part of Fc domain of human IgG with extracellular domain of T-cell inhibitory receptor CTLA4. It is approved for moderate-severe active RA not responding to Mtx. It can be combined with Mtx and other DMARDs, but not with TNFα antagonists due to greatly increased risk of infections.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 229.

questions.text: What medications fall under the WHO classification of "High Potency" medicines for Topical Steroids?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Class II and Class III

There are seven groups of topical steroid potency, ranging from ultra-high potency (group I) to low potency (group VII).

Class I is the most potent, and class VII is the least potent.
Potency depends on many factors, including the drug’s characteristics and concentration and the base in which it is used.
  • Super high-potency drugs are group I drugs
  • High-potency steroids are the steroids of groups II and III.
  • Medium-potency drugs are group IV drugs.
  • Lower mid-potency drugs are group V drugs.
  • Low-potency drugs are group VI drugs.
  • Least potency drugs are group VII drugs.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 955.

questions.text: What is the aprepitant's mode of action?
Which of the following antihistamines has the least sedative effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Chlorpheniramine 
 
  • Chlorpheniramine is an antihistamine that is commonly used to treat allergic conditions such as hay fever, allergic rhinitis, and hives.
  • Chlorpheniramine is considered to have a relatively low sedative effect compared to some other antihistamine.
  • Chlorpheniramine has a relatively lower ability to cross the blood-brain barrier compared to other antihistamines like Diphenhydramine or Promethazine. This is believed to be the reason why Chlorpheniramine is associated with less sedation.
Option1, 2 and 3 Drugs are high or moderately sedating compounds as they cross BBB easily.  



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 180.

choices.text: Belongs to a class of Drugs known as SERD

questions.text: Which of the following statements about fulvestrant is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Less effective than SERM
 
  • Fulvestrant is generally considered to be as effective as selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) such as tamoxifen in the treatment of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer. It is a pure estrogen antagonist with no agonist action. Fulvestrant is a selective estrogen-receptor down regulator (SERD).
  • Fulvestrant works differently from SERMs, as it acts as a selective estrogen receptor downregulator (SERD). It not only blocks estrogen receptors but also induces the degradation of the receptors, further reducing estrogen signaling.
  • By blocking and degrading estrogen receptors, fulvestrant helps to inhibit the growth and proliferation of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer cells.
  • It is longer acting and is administered once a month (250- 500mg) intramuscularly. It is generally well tolerated.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 337.

questions.text: Except for______, all of the following are appropriately matched.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (Option 4) Aromatase inhibitor-Triptorelin
 
  • Aromatase inhibitor - Triptorelin: This pairing is not appropriately matched.
  • Triptorelin is a medication that belongs to a class of drugs called gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists.
  • It is used to treat conditions such as endometriosis, prostate cancer, and precocious puberty.
  • It does not belong to the class of aromatase inhibitors, which are medications used to reduce estrogen levels in postmenopausal women with hormone receptor-positive breast cancer.
* [Extra Edge]: Drugs and their mechanism of action




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 265.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is a pure estrogen receptor antagonist?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Fulvestrant
 
  • Fulvestrant is generally considered to be as effective as selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) such as tamoxifen in the treatment of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer. It is a pure estrogen antagonist with no agonist action. Fulvestrant is a selective estrogen-receptor down regulator (SERD).
  • Fulvestrant works differently from SERMs, as it acts as a selective estrogen receptor downregulator (SERD). It not only blocks estrogen receptors but also induces the degradation of the receptors, further reducing estrogen signaling.
  • By blocking and degrading estrogen receptors, fulvestrant helps to inhibit the growth and proliferation of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer cells.
  • It is longer acting and is administered once a month (250- 500mg) intramuscularly. It is generally well tolerated.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 377.

questions.text: What is the GM-CSF used for neutropenia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Molgramostim
 
  • GM-CSF (Granulocyte-Macrophage Colony Stimulating Factor) is a cytokine that stimulates the bone marrow to produce white blood cells, including neutrophils.
  • Neutropenia is a condition in which the body has a low level of neutrophils, which can increase the risk of infections.
  • Molgramostim is a recombinant form of GM-CSF that is used to treat neutropenia by stimulating the production of neutrophils in the bone marrow.
  • Option 1, Filgrastim, is also a recombinant form of G-CSF that is used to treat neutropenia.
  • However, Filgrastim specifically stimulates the production of neutrophils, whereas Molgramostim stimulates the production of both neutrophils and macrophages.
  • Option 3, Romiplostim, is a thrombopoietin receptor agonist that is used to treat thrombocytopenia (a low level of platelets in the blood), not neutropenia.
  • Option 4, Eltrombopag, is also a thrombopoietin receptor agonist that is used to treat thrombocytopenia, not neutropenia.
Trick: -
Molgra mo stim- Graulocyte and Monocyte stimulator

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 936.

questions.text: Which antimalarial drug among the following has the greatest impact in lowering P. falciparum transmission?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Primaquine
 
  • Primaquine is an antimalarial medication that is primarily used for the prevention and treatment of relapse in certain types of malaria caused by Plasmodium vivax or Plasmodium ovale.
  • It is the only medication effective against the dormant liver stage of these malaria parasites, preventing the reemergence of the infection.
  •  By eliminating these hypnozoites, primaquine significantly reduces the reservoir of malaria parasites in the population.
  • It is also effective against gametocyte hence decreases the transmission of P. falciparum.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 878.

questions.text: What is denosumab used to treat?
A drug that is highly ionised:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Is excreted mainly by the kidney
 
  • Highly ionized drugs are mainly excreted by the kidneys. 
  • They are not reabsorbed from the renal tubules and are hence excreted unchanged by glomerular filtration. 
  • Dose reduction is necessary in renal impairment to avoid the accumulation of the drug and associated toxicity. 
  • The non-ionized forms of weak acids and bases undergo tubular reabsorption. 
Non ionized drugs can easily cross placental barrier, are well absorbed from intestine and accumulate in cellular lipids.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 37.

choices.text: Ranitidine combines with sucralfate and prevents its action
Combination produces serious side effects like agranulocytosis
Ranitidine increases the gastric pH so sucralfate is not able to act

questions.text: Why is it wrong to combine ranitidine and sucralfate in a patient with a peptic ulcer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Ranitidine increases the gastric pH so sucralfate is not able to act
  • Ranitidine reduces gastric acid secretion (Increasing the gastric pH) by blocking the H2 receptors on the parietal cells in the stomach.
  • Polymerisation of Sucralfate only occurs at acidic pH - this polymer forms a protective coating over the ulcerated or damaged areas in the stomach preventng ulcer from coming in contact with HCl.
  • When ranitidine and sucralfate are taken together, sucralfate polymerisation is affected due to higher pH - this reduces the efficacy of Sucralfate.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 21.

questions.text: Which enzyme does aminophylline inhibit?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Phosphodiesterase
 
  • Aminophylline group of drugs does Inhibition of phosphodiesterase (PDE) which degrades cyclic nucleotides intracellularly.
  • Consequently, the concentration of cyclic nucleotides is increased. Bronchodilatation, cardiac stimulation and vasodilatation occur and mediator release is inhibited when cAMP level rises in the bronchial/cardiac/vascular smooth muscle and in inflammatory cells, respectively.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 245.

questions.text: With which of the following receptors does theophylline interact antagonistically?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Adenosine receptors
 
  • Theophylline is a medication used as a bronchodilator to treat respiratory conditions such as asthma and COPD.
  • Theophylline, a medication used as a bronchodilator, acts as a non-selective adenosine receptor antagonist.
  • Adenosine receptors are G protein-coupled receptors that bind to the endogenous neurotransmitter adenosine.
  • By antagonizing adenosine receptors, theophylline inhibits their activity and produces various effects, including bronchodilation.

mechanism of action (MOA) of theophylline:

Action Effect
Phosphodiesterase (PDE) inhibition Increases cAMP, causing bronchodilation and reducing inflammation.
Adenosine receptor antagonism Prevents bronchoconstriction and reduces airway reactivity.
Enhances histone deacetylase activity Decreases release of inflammatory mediators.

Outcome: Promotes bronchodilation and anti-inflammatory effects, used in asthma and COPD management.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 245.

questions.text: Except for______, all of the following are known side effects of Phenytoin at therapeutic dosages.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Hypoglycemia
 
  • Phenytoin primarily affects the central nervous system and does not directly interfere with blood glucose regulation or the production and release of insulin.
  • While phenytoin can have various effects on the body, hypoglycemia is not a commonly reported side effect of the phenytoin at therapeutic dosages.
* Other options:
  • Long-term use of Phenytoin can interfere with folic acid metabolism, leading to megaloblastic anemia.
  • Phenytoin can cause gingival overgrowth or hypertrophy, leading to swollen and enlarged gums.
  • Prolonged use of Phenytoin has been associated with an increased risk of osteoporosis and decreased bone mineral density.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 441.

questions.text: What is an inverse agonist of the benzodiazepine receptor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Beta-carboline
 
  • Benzodiazepine receptors are found in the central nervous system and are targets for medications such as benzodiazepines, which are commonly used as sedatives, anxiolytics, and anticonvulsants.
  • An inverse agonist is a type of ligand that binds to the same receptor as an agonist but produces the opposite effect, reducing the constitutive activity of the receptor.
  • Beta-carbolines, including compounds such as Hermine and harmaline, act as inverse agonists of the benzodiazepine receptor.
  • They can produce anxiogenic (anxiety-promoting) effects and counteract the sedative and anxiolytic effects of benzodiazepines.
  • Beta-carbolines can be found in certain plants and are structurally different from benzodiazepines, but they interact with the same receptor.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 429.

questions.text: Except for ______, all of the following sulfonamide are used topically.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Sulfadiazine
 
  • Sulfonamides are a class of antimicrobial medications that inhibit the growth and reproduction of bacteria by interfering with the synthesis of folate.
  • When it comes to topical use, sulfonamides are commonly used in the treatment of various skin and eye infections.
  • Sulfadiazine is not typically used topically due to poor skin penetration. It has limited ability to effectively reach deeper layers of the skin where the infection may be present.
  • Systemic absorption of sulfadiazine can occur when applied topically, increasing the risk of adverse effects and systemic side effects.
  • Sulfadiazine is primarily administered orally or intravenously for the treatment of systemic infections
* Other options:
  • Sulfacetamide is a topical sulfonamide commonly used in the treatment of eye infections, such as conjunctivitis.
  • Silver sulfadiazine is a topical antimicrobial agent that is used for the prevention and treatment of burn wound infections.
  • Mafenide is a topical sulfonamide used as an antibacterial agent in the treatment of burns.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 757.

questions.text: The clavicle's ossification centre, which is used to certify their bone age for legal consent to marry, is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Sternal End

The legal age for marriage for girls and boys is 18 and 21 respectively.
Clavicle's secondary ossification center at the sternal end appears at 19-20 years of age(~2 years earlier in females) and is used to certify bone age for marriage. 

* Ossification centers of Clavicle: 
 
Site of Appearance              Time of                      Appearance     Time of Fusion
Two primary centers (medial/lateral)    5-6 weeks in utero       45th day of             Intrauterine life
Secondary center at Sternal(medial) end.    19-20 years (2    years earlier in females)         25th Year
Secondary center at Acromial end            20 year       Immediately

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 62.

choices.text: Hemorrhage on the posterior surface of the esophagus
Definitive sign of death due to manual strangulation
Caused by leakage of blood from venous plexus after death

questions.text: Except for ______, each of the following statements regarding the Prinsloo Gorden Artefact is accurate.
questions.solution:
The correct option is 3. "Definitive sign of death due to manual strangulation."
  • The Prinsloo Gorden Artefact is a hemorrhage on the posterior surface of the esophagus, which was first described by Prinsloo and Gordon.
  • However, it is not a definitive sign of death due to manual strangulation.
  • The Prinsloo Gorden Artefact is a post-mortem finding that is commonly seen in cases of manual strangulation. It is caused by the rupture of the small veins in the mucosa of the posterior wall of the esophagus due to the pressure applied during the act of strangulation.
  • The hemorrhage appears as a linear or crescent-shaped mark on the posterior wall of the esophagus and is usually located between the level of the cricoid cartilage and the bifurcation of the trachea.
  • While the presence of the Prinsloo Gorden Artefact is highly suggestive of death due to manual strangulation, it is not a definitive sign.
  • Other causes of the hemorrhage, such as forceful vomiting or resuscitation attempts, can also result in the appearance of the artefact.
  • Therefore, a thorough investigation, including a detailed examination of the body and the circumstances surrounding the death, is necessary to determine the cause and manner of death.
Prinsloo and Gordon artefact is seen in all types of autopsies and is present over posterior surface of esophagus, trachea and anterior longitudnal ligament of cervical spine. It is due to postmortem staining. It must not be confused as hemorrhage which can cause misinterpretation the case as a manual strangulation. That is why before dissection neck structures must be inspected in situ. Also before opening neck, head and thorax must be opened to achieve bloodless neck dissection.

Reference: Pollanen MS. Pitfalls and Artifacts in the Neck at Autopsy. Acad Forensic Pathol. 2016 Mar;6(1):45-62. doi: 10.23907/2016.005. Epub 2016 Mar 1. PMID: 31239872; PMCID: PMC6474509.

choices.text: Rule is in relation to blunt injuries of cranium
Used to determine the sequence of bullet shots
The test depends on observing the fracture lines
Valuable in cases of multiple bullet injuries occurring simultaneously

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Puppe's rule is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1 Rule is in relation to blunt injuries of cranium
+ Puppe’s rule:
  • In cases of multiple gunshot wounds of the skull, determination of the sequence in which the wounds took place is done by Puppe’s rule.
  • Puppe's rule was actually developed by Madea in relation to bullet injuries, but it is applicable to any multiple blunt forces causing fracture.
  • The fractures from 1st injury develop normally, while those caused by subsequent injury are stopped where they intersect with the existent fracture lines.
  • This pattern of radical fracture lines allows the determination of sequence of gun shots.


Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 225.

questions.text: On autopsy, a soft, friable extradural hematoma that resembles a honeycomb is discovered in:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Heat Hematoma.

When exposed to increased heat, boiling of blood followed by rupture of Dural venous sinuses occurs. when this blood clots, it gives a honeycomb appearance.

It mimics antemortem extradural hemorrhage but can be differentiated by distribution: 
  • Antemortem EDH – unilateral 
  • Heat Hematoma – bilateral and diffuse 
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 324.

questions.text: A condition known as 'la facies sympathique' is present in cases of:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Hanging.
  • In a patient of hanging, the ligature knot puts a pressure on the opposite Cervical Sympathetic ganglion. This causes the eye on the opposite side of the knot to remain open and the pupil gets dilated.
  • A common misconception is that cervical ganglion of the same side as the ligature knot gets compressed which is wrong. In a case of hanging the fixed knot almost never comes in contact with the skin (ligature does not encircle the neck completely). Maximum pressure is exerted on the opposite side of the knot and thus the opposite cervical ganglion gets compressed. The eye on that side is dilated.
  • This is caused by the increased pressure in the veins of the head and neck due to the obstruction of blood flow from the heart to the head. Option 1, Hanging, is the correct answer because this condition is specific to death by hanging and is not present in other causes of death such as strangulation, myocardial insufficiency, or railway accidents. In cases of strangulation, the appearance of the face may be different due to the different mechanism of death.
  • Myocardial insufficiency and railway accidents are also not associated with the characteristic appearance of the face seen in 'le facies sympathique'.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 344.

questions.text: What is piquerism connected to:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Paraphilia

Picquerism is the sexual gratification yielded from biting or the use of knives and sharp objects to pierce, stab, or slash the skin.

Other paraphilias:
  • Exhibitionism: Repeated and intense sexual arousal from exposing one’s genitals to unsuspecting individuals 
  • Voyeurism: recurrent and intense sexual arousal. Arousal from observing others in sexual activity or undressing without their knowledge or consent 
  • Fetishism: persistent and intense sexual arousal or gratification through the use of non-living objects such as shoes, underwear or specific body parts e.g. feet
  • Frotteurism: sexual arousal achieved by rubbing once genitals against a non-consenting person in crowded public places.
  • Pedophilia: sexual attraction to prepubescent children typically under the age of 13 
  • Sadism: sexual arousal and gratification from inflicting physical or psychological pain, suffering or humiliation upon others
  • Masochism: sexual harassment and gratification from receiving physical or psychological pain suffering and humiliation
  • Zoophilia: sexual attraction to animals involving sexual contact or fantasies with animals
  • Coprophilia: sexual harassment and gratification from faeces (liking the smell, feel or taste) or the act of defecation
  • Necrophilia: sexual attraction and engagement in sexual acts with corpses
  • Klismaphilia: Sexual arousal and gratification from receiving enemas.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 431.

questions.text: What is it known as when someone strips off and runs around naked in public?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Streaking.

Streaking refers to the act of running naked or partially naked in public, typically in a spontaneous and unplanned manner.
It is often considered a form of exhibitionism, where individuals seek a thrill or sense of liberation by breaking societal norms regarding public nudity.

Option 1: Sexual arousal achieved by rubbing once genitals against a non-consenting person in crowded public places.

Option 2: Flashing refers to the act of deliberately exposing one's genitals to others without their consent or in inappropriate contexts. It typically involves quickly and unexpectedly revealing one's genitals to shock, intimidate, or sexually gratify oneself.

Option 3: Mooning refers to the act of intentionally exposing one's buttocks to others.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 431.

questions.text: Force-feeding of prisoners who are on hunger strike is:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Lawful under article 21 of the constitution.

Force-feeding of prisoners who are on a hunger strike could potentially be considered lawful under Article 21 if it is done in exceptional circumstances to protect the life of the prisoner. The State's duty to preserve life may outweigh the individual's right to refuse food when it poses an imminent threat to their life

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 55.

questions.text: Except for______,all of the following lead to miosis.
Methyl-isocyanate, the gas responsible for the Bhopal gas tragedy, caused deaths mainly by:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Pulmonary Edema.

Methyl isocyanate poisoning is fatal, immediate death occurs due to respiratory failure from pulmonary edema.
  • Most common route of exposure – inhalation 
  • Toxicity within 1-4 hours of exposure
  • Clinical features – cough, dyspnea, chest pain, lacrimation, edema
  • Prolonged exposure leads to Acute lung injury, cardiac arrest and death
  • Mx – Only supportive treatment can be given.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 624.

questions.text: How can you compute incidence rates?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  Cohort study 

A long-term follow-up cohort study can compute incidence rate. Here a cohort group of individuals with common characteristics are selected and divided into two groups, one having risk factors and other without risk factors.

Prevalence is measured with cross-sectional study.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 87.

questions.text: Which of the following will result in an increase in illness prevalence?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3:  Longer duration of disease

Longer duration of disease leads to increased prevalence as the number of new individuals getting affected remain the same (incidence remains same)  and since there is no cure or death the number of people suffering from the disease at a given point in time is increased.

Reason:
Prevalence=incidence × duration

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 69.
