questions.text: What one of the following is not true regarding the lepromin test?
questions.solution:
• The lepromin test is not a diagnostic test.
  • It is used as an aid in classifying the type of leprosy and in assessing the immune response to the Mycobacterium leprae bacterium.
  • Early lepromin test reaction is called Mitsuda and late is called Fernandez. 
  • It is usually negative in the first 6 months of life and can be converted to positive by BCG vaccination.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 368.

questions.text: What is the best definition of "Urban" and "Rural," two qualitative categories into which data is divided?
questions.solution:
Option 2, "Ordinal data," is the correct answer for the given question.
  • Urban and rural are qualitative categories that are used to describe the characteristics of a geographical area. Urban areas are typically densely populated areas with a high concentration of buildings, businesses, and infrastructure. In contrast, rural areas are sparsely populated areas with a low concentration of buildings and infrastructure.
  • Ordinal data is a type of data that can be ranked or ordered, but the differences between the values are not necessarily equal. In the case of the given question, "urban" and "rural" are qualitative categories that can be ranked based on their level of urbanization. However, the difference between the two categories is not necessarily equal.
  • Therefore, the best definition for "urban" and "rural" is "ordinal data."
  • To further clarify, here are brief definitions of other types of data: - Normal data: A type of data that follows a normal distribution, also known as a bell curve. 
  • Interval data: A type of data that has equal intervals between values, but there is no true zero point.
  • Ratio data: A type of data that has equal intervals between values and a true zero point.
Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 3.

choices.text: Achieve comparability between study and control groups

questions.text: Double blinding in clinical studies is done for what reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Avoid observer and subject bias

Blinding is done to reduce and prevent bias.
  • Single – subject is blind.
  • Double – subject and observer both are blind.
  • Triple – subject, observer, analyser are blind.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 98.

questions.text: Except for_______, all of the strategies listed below are antilarval defences.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Malathion.
 
  • Malathion is an insecticide used for adult mosquito control and is not considered an antilarval defense.
  • The other options (Intermittent irrigation, Paris green, and Gambusia affinis) are strategies used to control mosquito larvae, which are the immature stages of mosquitoes.
  • Intermittent irrigation is a technique where water is periodically drained from breeding sites, disrupting the mosquito life cycle.
  • Paris green mainly kills larvae who are surface feeders which include Anopheles larvae.
  • The larvivorous fishes that can be used for biological control include:
    • Gambusia affinis
    • Lebister reticulatus (Barbados Millions)
    • Poecilia 


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 898.

questions.text: In accordance with international health regulations, yellow fever cannot spread if the aedes aegypti index stays below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 1%
 
  • Aedes aegypti index, i.e., the ratio between the number of houses in an area where breeding of Aedes are found and the total number of houses examined in that area. This index is kept at zero at all ports.
  • The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that the Aedes aegypti index be kept below 1% to prevent the spread of yellow fever.
  • If the Aedes aegypti index is above 1%, it means that there is a high risk of yellow fever transmission in the area. This is because Aedes aegypti mosquitoes are the main vector for yellow fever.
  • There are a number of things that can be done to keep the Aedes aegypti index below 1%, including:
  1. Eliminating mosquito breeding sites
  2. Using insect repellent
  3. Wearing long sleeves and pants
  4. Getting vaccinated against yellow fever

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 329.

questions.text: What specific ingredients are in the malaria vaccine?
questions.solution:
- The malaria vaccine (such as RTS,S/AS01, also known as Mosquirix) uses the circumsporozoite protein of Plasmodium falciparum, which is the protein expressed on the surface of sporozoites, the stage of the parasite that infects the liver.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 314.

questions.text: Which polio virus strains are included in the bivalent oral polio vaccine?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: 1 & 3
 
  • OPV initially consisted of a mixture of live attenuated poliovirus strains of each of the three serotypes. 
  • OPV used in India contained, Type 1 virus 10 lakh, Type 2 virus 2 lakh and Type 3 virus 3 lakh TC ID50 per dose (0.5 ml). 
  • Trivalent vaccine has now been replaced by bivalent OPV, by removing the type 2 component from immunisation programmes (OPV switch) ad Type 2 virus is eliminated. 
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 241.

choices.text: Time between point where the diagnosis is made by screening test to usual diagnosis
Time between usual time of diagnosis and outcome

questions.text: How is lead time defined?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Time between point where the diagnosis is made by screening test to usual diagnosis

Lead time is the duration between first possible time when disease can be detected and the usual time of diagnosis.

  • Lead time is defined as the amount of time gained by early detection of a disease through screening. It is the difference between the time of diagnosis through screening and the time of diagnosis without screening.
  • Therefore, the correct option is 2. Time between point where the diagnosis is made by screening test to usual diagnosis.
  • Option 1 is incorrect because it refers to the time between diagnosis and treatment, which is not the same as lead time.
  • Option 3 is incorrect because it refers to the time between disease onset and outcome, which is also not the same as lead time.
  • Option 4 is incorrect because it refers to the time between usual time of diagnosis and outcome, which is again not the same as lead time.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 149.

questions.text: Epidemiological triangle for infectious diseases differs epidemiological triad with respect to ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Time

Host, agent and environment are the three factors present in both epidemiological triad and epidemiological triangle. The difference in both is “time” which is a part of epidemiological triangle.

            
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 39, 40.

questions.text: When distributions are asymmetrical or moderately skewed:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Mode = 3 Median - 2 Mean

STANDARD NORMAL DISTRIBUTION CURVE –



Here,
MEAN = MEDIAN = MODE = 0


Skewed Data –



MODE = 3 MEDIAN – 2 MEAN

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 8.

questions.text: In the absence of microscopy, what is the preferred treatment for falciparum malaria when bivalent RDT is employed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: ACT + Primaquine
 
  • When the microscopy is not available, a bivalent RDT (Rapid Diagnostic Test) can be employed to diagnose malaria by detecting specific antigens produced by the Plasmodium falciparum parasite.
  • If a bivalent rapid diagnostic test (RDT) is positive for Plasmodium falciparum malaria, the preferred treatment is an artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) + primaquine.
  • ACTs are the most effective treatment for falciparum malaria.
  • Primaquine is effective in preventing relapses.

Rx of P. falciparum:


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 309.

questions.text: Except for ______, all of the following traits apply to health indicators.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Affordability

Health indicators measure different aspects of health of a population.
Examples include – life expectancy, infant mortality, disability rates

Characteristics of health indicators :
  • Valid
  • Reliable
  • Sensitive
  • Specific
  • Feasible
  • Relevant
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 24.

questions.text: Which triage category is designated for ambulatory walking wounded patients?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Green.
 
  • Triage is the process of sorting patients based on the severity of their condition to prioritize medical care during mass casualty incidents or disasters.
  • The Green triage category is designated for "walking wounded" or ambulatory patients with minor injuries or illnesses that do not require immediate medical attention.
  • These patients can be treated on-site or referred to less critical areas for medical evaluation and care.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 923.

questions.text: For casual reading, what level of illumination (lux) is advised:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: 100.
 
  • For casual reading or general indoor activities, a recommended level of illumination is around 100 lux.
  • Lux is a unit of measurement for illuminance, which is the amount of light falling on a surface.
  • Adequate lighting is important for reading and other activities to reduce eye strain and ensure a comfortable environment.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 868.

questions.text: For the —- people in the plains and the —- population in the tribal areas, one village health worker is advised.
questions.solution:
For the 5000 people in the plains and the 3000 population in the tribal areas, one village health worker is advised.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 705.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Didactic communication is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Democratic
 
  • Didactic communication is a one-way communication process, where information is imparted from the speaker (or teacher) to the audience (or learners) without active participation or feedback from the audience.
  • Didactic communication is not characterized by democratic or participatory interactions. It is the opposite, where the communication is primarily top-down, with the speaker being the sole authority delivering information to the audience.




Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 991.

questions.text: The phase of full family extension ends when or as soon as:
Which type of management technique is exemplified by PERT?
Aplastic anemia, Pancreatic exocrine insufficiency, small height, with skeletal anomalies point to the diagnosis of:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Shwachman-Diamond syndrome.

Shwachman-Diamond syndrome (SDS) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by:
 
  • Aplastic anemia (condition where the bone marrow fails to produce enough blood cells).
  • Pancreatic exocrine insufficiency (pancreas does not produce enough digestive enzymes).
  • Short stature.
  • Skeletal anomalies (abnormalities in the bones).




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 794.

questions.text: Which of the characteristics is NOT present in DIC?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Hyperfibrinogenemia.
 
  • Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC) is a life-threatening disorder involving abnormal blood clotting, excessive bleeding, widespread microvascular thrombosis, and potential organ damage.
 
  • Hyperfibrinogenemia is not a characteristic of DIC; instead, fibrinogen levels are typically decreased due to its consumption during clot formation.
  • D- dimer and Fibrin Degraded Products are a marker of DIC. 

Classic features of DIC:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 915-917.

questions.text: What does a direct anti-globulin (Coombs) test that is positive mean?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Hemolytic disease
 
  • A positive direct anti-globulin (Coombs) test indicates the presence of antibodies or complement proteins bound to the surface of red blood cells.
  • This finding suggests immune-mediated hemolysis, where the immune system targets and destroys red blood cells.
  • Hemolytic disease refers to a condition characterized by increased destruction of red blood cells.
  • The positive Coombs test helps confirm the diagnosis of immune-mediated hemolytic diseases such as autoimmune hemolytic anemia and hemolytic disease of the newborn.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 462.

choices.text: Platelets bear the antigens of ABO system
Platelet products usually do not contain donor plasma

questions.text: What is incorrect about platelet transfusions?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Platelets carry the Rh antigen.
 
  • Platelets do not express Rh antigens, they contain small numbers of intact red blood cells or fragments, which can lead to alloimmunization in the recipient. Alloimmunization to the RhD antigen may occur when platelets obtained from RhD-positive donors are transfused to RhD-negative recipients.
 
  • Platelets express ABO antigens and are collected in plasma, which contains ABO antibodies as would be consistent with the donor ABO group. Platelet ABO antigens that are incompatible with recipient ABO antibodies may have accelerated clearance from circulation and result in lower count increments. ABO antibodies that are passively transferred from donor plasma may result in hemolysis of recipient red blood cells.
 
  • Platelet products may contain some donor plasma, but the amount is usually very small. To minimize the risk of transfusion reactions, platelet products are usually prepared by a process called apheresis, which separates platelets from the donor's blood and returns the rest of the blood components back to the donor. 



Reference: Dunbar, Nancy M. “Does ABO and RhD matching matter for platelet transfusion?.” Hematology. American Society of Hematology. Education Program vol. 2020,1 (2020): 512-517. doi:10.1182/hematology.2020000135. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7727583/

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Pulsus Bigeminus is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Compensatory pause is absent.
 
  • Pulsus bigeminus is characterized by an irregular rhythm with every other beat occurring prematurely, resulting in a paired (coupled) beat. 
  • The premature beat is followed by a compensatory pause, which is a brief pause before the next regular heartbeat. 
  • This compensatory pause is a key feature that helps distinguish pulsus bigeminus from other irregular rhythms.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1818, 1819, 1915.

questions.text: Rytand's murmur appears in:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: A-V Block.
  • Rytand's murmur is a diastolic murmur that is heard in patients with complete atrioventricular (A-V) block.
  • It is a mid-late blowing diastolic murmur heard occasionally in patients with complete atrioventricular heart block. Best heard at the apex, and often confused with mitral stenosis (no opening snap).






Reference: An auricular diastolic murmur with heart block in elderly patients, David A. Rytand, American Heart Journal, Volume 32, Issue 5, 1946, Pages 579-598, ISSN 0002-8703, https://doi.org/10.1016/0002-8703(46)90667-9.
(https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0002870346906679)

questions.text: The sign of Auenbrugger is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Percardial Effusion.
 
  • Auenbrugger's sign, also known as "Percussion Dullness," is a physical sign seen in patients with pericardial effusion. It can be seen as a bulge in the epigastrium.
  • It is caused by the accumulation of fluid around the heart, leading to upward and leftward displacement of the heart, which can be felt by palpating the chest wall.
  • Constrictive pericarditis may cause a similar sign called Kussmaul's sign.



Reference: Rastogi, Vaibhav et al. “Abdominal Physical Signs of Inspection and Medical Eponyms.” Clinical medicine & research vol. 17,3-4 (2019): 115-126. doi:10.3121/cmr.2019.1420. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6886890/

choices.text: Characterised by pleuritic chest pain, leukocytosis and elevated ESR

questions.text: Which statement concerning the Dressler syndrome is false?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Steroids from the mainstay of treatment.
 
  • Dressler syndrome, also known as post–myocardial infarction syndrome, Dressler syndrome usually occurs 1 to 8 weeks after infarction
  • Clinically, patients with Dressler syndrome have malaise, fever, pericardial discomfort, leukocytosis, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), and a pericardial effusion.
  • The cause of post-MI syndrome s not clearly established, although detection of antibodies to cardiac tissue suggests an immunopathologic process.
  • Treatment is with Aspirin, 650 mg as often as every 4 hours, may be effective. Glucocorticosteroids and NSAIDs are best avoided in patients with Dressler syndrome within 4 weeks of STEMI because of their potential to impair infarct healing, cause ventricular rupture, and increase coronary vascular resistance


Reference: Braunwald's Heart Disease: A Textbook of Cardiovascular Medicine, 11th edition, Page no 1163.

questions.text: What is correct about a pneumothorax?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Decreased Chest Expansion.
 
  • Pneumothorax is a condition where air accumulates in the pleural space, causing partial or complete collapse of the lung.
  • A characteristic sign of a pneumothorax is decreased chest expansion on the affected side due to the collapsed lung's limited ability to expand during breathing.
  • Other signs include:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2200.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 373, 374.

questions.text: Samter's Triad describes the relationship between aspirin sensitive asthma and:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Nasal polyp

Samter’s Triad or Aspirin sensitive asthma is triad of -
Aspirin intolerance, Bronchial Asthma and Nasal Polyps.

Patients suffering from Samter’s Triad should avoid Aspirin and NSAIDs which inhibit the COX-1 Pathway leading to an acute attack of Asthma and the development of Nasal Polyps later on.
Treatment includes Endoscopic sinus surgery for nasal polyps and aspirin desensitization.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 219

questions.text: What results in tropical pulmonary eosinophilia?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Occult filariasis.
 
  • TPE is a hypersensitivity reaction to filarial parasites, Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi, transmitted through mosquito bites causing lymphatic filariasis.
  • Symptoms : Chronic cough, wheezing, and shortness of breath, often exacerbated at night (nocturnal).
  • Peripheral eosinophilia with an absolute eosinophil count > 5000 is a typical finding in TPE.
  • Treatment involves using diethylcarbamazine (DEC) to eliminate the microfilariae.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1781.

questions.text: The APC gene is mutated in every single one of the genetic disorders listed below that are linked to colorectal cancer, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Lynch Syndrome 
 
  • The APC (adenomatous polyposis coli) gene is a tumor suppressor gene involved in the regulation of cell growth and division.
  • Mutations in the APC gene are associated with various forms of familial colorectal cancer syndromes.
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), Gardner's syndrome, and Turcot's syndrome are all linked to mutations in the APC gene.
  • However, Lynch syndrome, also known as hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), is caused by mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes and not the APC gene.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 813.

questions.text: A male adolescent appears with hypercalciuria, nephrocalcinosis, metabolic alkalosis, and hypokalemia. He has normal blood pressure. It is highly likely that:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Bartter Syndrome
 
  • The case involves a male adolescent with hypercalciuria, nephrocalcinosis, metabolic alkalosis, and hypokalemia.
  • These symptoms, along with normal blood pressure, are highly suggestive of Bartter Syndrome.
  • Bartter Syndrome is a rare genetic disorder affecting kidney salt reabsorption, leading to potassium, chloride, and sodium loss in the urine, resulting in hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2286, 2287, 2293.

questions.text: Except for_____, all of the following laboratory characteristics are linked to tumor lysis syndrome.
questions.solution: Tumor lysis syndrome is characterized by hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia and hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia - not hypercalcemia. Hypocalcemia occurs due to the chelation of calcium by intracellular phosphate released extracellularly due to tumor cell death.

questions.text: In dialysis patients, what trace element is linked to the risk of osteomalacia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Aluminium
 
  • In dialysis patients, there is a risk of developing osteomalacia.
  • Osteomalacia is a softening of the bones that can cause pain, weakness, and fractures. It is caused by a deficiency of vitamin D, which is needed for the bones to absorb calcium.
  • Aluminium toxicity is linked to the development of osteomalacia in dialysis patients.
  • Excess aluminium accumulation can occur in these patients due to the use of aluminium-containing phosphate binders or exposure to aluminium in the dialysis process.
  • Prolonged exposure to high levels of aluminium in the dialysis fluid can lead to the accumulation of aluminium in the bones, causing osteomalacia



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2307, 2308.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about osmotic diarrhoea is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Osmol gap < 50
 
  • Osmotic diarrhea is caused by osmotically active solutes in the stool, leading to watery diarrhea.
  • The osmolar gap, which measures the difference between stool and plasma osmolality, is typically greater than 50 in osmotic diarrhea.
  • Stool osmotic gap is calculated as 290 mOsm/kg − 2 × (stool Na + stool K). 290 mOsm/kg is the presumed stool osmolality, and the measured concentration of sodium and potassium cations is doubled to account for the corresponding anions which must be present.
  • The characteristic features of osmotic diarrhea:
    • Watery diarrhea. The stool is typically watery with a volume of >1 L/day.
    • Osmolar gap > 50.
    • Stool does not contain blood, pus, or mucus.
    • Stool does not contain blood, pus, or mucus.
    • Diarrhea stops after fasting. If the patient fasts, the diarrhea will stop, as there will be no food in the intestine to cause the osmotic effect.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 303.

questions.text: All stomach conditions are premalignant, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Hiatus Hernia
 
  • Hiatus hernia is not considered premalignant.
  • It is a condition where a portion of the stomach protrudes through the diaphragm into the chest cavity.
  • While hiatus hernia can cause symptoms like acid reflux, it is not directly associated with an increased risk of malignancy or cancer development in the same way that conditions like atrophic gastritis or pernicious anemia are.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 629, 630.

choices.text: May be confused with Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Menetrier disease is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Usually increased acid secretion
 
  • Menetrier disease is characterized by gross hypertrophy of the gastric mucosal folds, protein-losing gastropathy, and hypochlorhydria.
  • This disease is caused by the overexpression of TGF- alpha, which increases the growth of mucous cells.
  • The increased number of mucous cells leads to giant rugal folds.
  • The resulting excessive production of mucous in the stomach causes an increased loss of proteins and chloride from the body.
  • Patients with Menetrier disease usually present with diarrhea, hypoproteinemia, and anemia.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2458.

questions.text: Which antibodies are ordinarily high in primary biliary Cholangitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Antimitochondrial antibodies 

Primary Biliary Cholangitis (PBC)
  • PBC is an autoimmune disease characterized by nonsuppurative, inflammatory destruction of small and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Large intrahepatic ducts and the extrahepatic biliary tree are not involved.
  • Disease of middle-aged women, with a female predominance of 9:1.
  • Antimitochondrial antibodies are the most characteristic laboratory finding in PBC.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2627.

questions.text: What exactly does C-ANCA positivity refer to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Wegener's Granulomatosis
 
  • C-ANCA (cytoplasmic antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody) positivity refers to the presence of specific antibodies targeting neutrophil cytoplasmic antigens.
  • It is most commonly associated with Wegener's granulomatosis, a systemic autoimmune disease characterized by inflammation of blood vessels in multiple organs.
  • C-ANCA antibodies primarily target proteinase 3 (PR3), an enzyme found in neutrophil granules.
  • The detection of C-ANCA antibodies in a patient's blood is an important diagnostic marker for Wegener's granulomatosis.
ANCA Memorizing trick:- 
PCM- p-ANCA- Churg's Strauss, Microscopic polyangitis 
c-ANCA- Wegener's 






Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 514.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Churg Strauss Syndrome is false?
Treatment of choice in acute Sarcoidosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Prednisolone
 
  • Sarcoidosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that forms granulomas in various organs.
  • Acute sarcoidosis is a severe form of sarcoidosis with symptoms like fever, cough, and chest pain.
  • Prednisolone is the treatment of choice for acute sarcoidosis, as it suppresses the immune response and reduces inflammation.
  • Other treatments for severe cases include cyclophosphamide, methotrexate, and infliximab.

Sarcoidosis treatment :





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2835.

choices.text: 6 months of steroids +12-24 months maintenance doses

questions.text: The preferred course of treatment for acute sarcoidosis with multiple organ involvement is:
questions.solution:
Correct answer 1
  • The preferred course of treatment of Sarcoidosis is 3-6 months of Steroids tapered gradually followed by a maintenance dose for 12-24 months

Management of Acute Sarcoidosis:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2835, 2836.
Melani, Andrea S et al. “A Comprehensive Review of Sarcoidosis Treatment for Pulmonologists.” Pulmonary therapy vol. 7,2 (2021): 325-344. doi:10.1007/s41030-021-00160-x. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8589889/

questions.text: Most virulent form of Medullary carcinoma thyroid is seen in which type of MEN syndrome:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: MEN - 2B
 
  • Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid (MCT) is a thyroid cancer arising from C-cells.
  • MCT can be linked to multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndromes, genetic disorders causing tumors in multiple endocrine glands.
  • MEN-2B is the most virulent form of MCT, characterized by MCT, pheochromocytoma, and mucosal neuromas.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2988, 2989.

questions.text: Primary Adrenal Insufficiency causes all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Increased protein breakdown 
 
  • Addison's disease is a primary adrenal insufficiency in which the adrenal is unable to secrete adequate amounts of cortisol (glucocorticoid), aldosterone (mineralocorticoid), and sex hormones. The most common cause of Addison's disease is autoimmune adrenalitis. 
  • Symptoms include:
  1. Low blood pressure
  2. Decrease in extracellular fluid (ECF)
  3. Decreased sodium-potassium ratio  due to reduced aldosterone levels.
  • However, increased protein breakdown (D) is not a typical symptom of primary adrenal insufficiency. People with Addison's disease may actually have increased protein levels in their blood as their bodies try to conserve protein.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2971, 2972.

questions.text: All of the following are caused by primary adrenal insufficiency, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Elevated plasma volume 
 
  • Addison's disease is a primary adrenal insufficiency in which the adrenal is unable to secrete adequate amounts of cortisol (glucocorticoid), aldosterone (mineralocorticoid), and sex hormones. The most common cause of Addison's disease is autoimmune adrenalitis. 
  • The key symptoms include:
         A. Increased urine output
         B. Weight loss with edema,
         C. Decreased urine osmolarity
  • There is decreased retention of sodium and water in the body, which leads to a decrease in plasma volume

Clinical features of Addison’s disease:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2971, 2972.

questions.text: The syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) has which of the following characteristics?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Hypertension
 
  • Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone ADH release (SIADH) is a condition where there is an unsuppressed release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) from the pituitary gland or nonpituitary sources or its continued action on vasopressin receptors.
 
  • Clinical features of SIADH:
    • Hyponatremia (low blood sodium levels)
    • Decreased urination
    • Confusion
    • Fatigue
    • Weakness
    • Muscle cramps
    • High blood pressure- due to increased blood volume 

The other given clinical features are more classic of pheochromocytoma.

Laboratory findings of SIADH :





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 342, 2924.

questions.text: Except for________, the Classic Triad of Pheochromocytoma includes episodes of all of the following.

choices.text: Extensors more than flexors in Lower limb
Flexors more than extensors in Upper Limb
Antigravity muscles are affected in upper limb
Antigravity muscles are spared in upper limb

questions.text: As a result of the distribution of weakness in pyramidal tract lesions:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Antigravity muscles are affected in upper limb
 
  • Pyramidal tract lesions result from damage to the corticospinal tracts, responsible for voluntary movement control.
  • Characterized by spasticity, increased muscle tone, and exaggerated reflexes.
  • Presents with weakness on one side of the body (hemiparesis) if the lesion is unilateral.
  • Unilateral or bilateral weakness of the upper limb extensors and lower limb flexors (“pyramidal weakness”) suggests a lesion of the pyramidal tract.
  • Lower limb weakness is greater than upper limb weakness.
  • Distal muscles of the limbs are more affected than proximal muscles.
  • Babinski sign may be present (upward extension of the big toe and fanning of other toes upon foot stimulation).
  • Commonly observed in conditions like stroke, multiple sclerosis, and traumatic brain or spinal cord injuries.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 165, 3280.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Guillain-Barré syndrome is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Descending
 
  • Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is an autoimmune disorder affecting the peripheral nervous system.
  • GBS manifests as a rapidly evolving areflexic motor paralysis with or without sensory disturbance. The usual pattern is an ascending paralysis that may be first noticed as rubbery legs.
  • It is characterized by inflammation and demyelination of nerves, leading to weakness, numbness, and tingling in the limbs.
  • GBS typically follows an ascending pattern; it usually starts in the feet and hands and moves up the body.
  • Cranial nerves can also be affected, leading to issues with facial, eye, and mouth control.
  • GBS is both inflammatory and demyelinating in nature, involving damage to the protective sheath surrounding nerves.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3501.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Tabes Dorsalis is untrue?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Deep tendon reflexes are brisk
 
  • Tabes dorsalis (or syphilitic myelopathy) is a slow degeneration and demyelination of the neural tracts.
  • It is seen in tertiary syphilis.
  • It primarily involves the dorsal columns of the spinal cord and dorsal roots.

Clinical features:
  • Loss of reflexes in lower limbs 
  • Romberg's sign
  • Bilateral Argyll Robertson pupils - accommodation reflex present, pupillary reflex absent 
  • Loss of position sense and vibration
  • Stabbing/pricking pain in the legs - this is fleeting or repetitive
  • Ataxia of the legs and gait disturbances
  • Paresthesias
  • Bladder disturbances 
  • Acute abdominal pain with vomiting - visceral crisis 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3454.

questions.text: It is usual to see neurodegeneration and iron buildup in the basal ganglia in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hallervorden-Spatz Disease
 
  • Pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN) formerly known as Hallervorden-Spatz disease caused by PANK2 gene mutation is the most common form of Neurodegeneration with Brain Iron Accumulation (NBIA) and is manifested as a combination of dystonia (hyperkinetic), parkinsonism (hypokinetic), and spasticity.
 
  • T2W-MRI shows the characteristic eye of the tiger sign due to iron accumulation in globus pallidus.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3409.

questions.text: All of the following are included in the Balint's syndrome triad, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Opsoclonus
 
  • Balint's syndrome is a rare neurological disorder that is characterized by three main features:
    • Optic ataxia (inability to reach for or point to objects that are seen in the periphery of the visual field).
    • Simultanagnosia (inability to see multiple objects in a single visual scene).
    • Ocular apraxia (inability to voluntarily move the eyes to a specific location).
 
  • Opsoclonus is a rare movement disorder that is characterized by involuntary, rapid, jerky eye movements. It is not a feature of Balint's syndrome.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3329.

questions.text: Quinn's wheel chair sign is used as a standard Red Flag Sign in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Idiopathic Parkinsonism

Wheelchair sign is seen with levodopa therapy in Parkinsonism / Paralysis agitans patients.
 
  • Usage of levodopa leads to on and off phenomenon.
  • When Levodopa starts acting the akinetic wheelchair bound patient will be in a position to get out of the chair and start pushing it.
  • When the effect weans off the same patient will be restricted to wheelchair.



Reference: Roongroj Bhidayasiri, Jirada Sringean, Stephen G. Reich, Carlo Colosimo,
Red flags phenotyping: A systematic review on clinical features in atypical parkinsonian disorders, Parkinsonism & Related Disorders, Volume 59, 2019, doi: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.parkreldis.2018.10.009. URL: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1353802018304371

questions.text: Patients with severe kyphoscoliosis who get abnormal results on their preoperative pulmonary function tests include:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Increased RV/TLC
 
  • Patients with severe kyphoscoliosis often have restrictive lung disease due to the impaired movement of the chest wall and decreased lung expansion.
  • Kyphoscoliosisis a ventilation defect due to Chest wall abnormality. In such cases, RV remains unchanged, whereas TLC is unchanged or slightly reduced leading to an Normal to increased RV/TLC ratio on pulmonary function tests.
  • Rest all other options are false





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2137, 2138.

questions.text: Which of the following tests will confirm the diagnosis in a patient with asthmatic clinical symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Diurnal variation in PEF > 10 Percent
 
  • Asthma is a chronic respiratory condition characterized by airway inflammation and narrowing, leading to breathing difficulties.
  • Specific finding in asthma: Diurnal variation in PEF >10%, with lower values in the morning due to increased airway inflammation.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2154, 2155.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about chronic bronchitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Predominant symptom is Dyspnea
 
  • Chronic bronchitis is a type of COPD with airway inflammation and narrowing, leading to symptoms like cough, sputum production, dyspnea, wheezing, and chest tightness.
  • The predominant symptom in chronic bronchitis is a productive cough lasting at least three months per year for two consecutive years.
  • "Blue Bloaters" (Option 2) is a term used for chronic bronchitis patients with cyanosis and peripheral edema due to low oxygen levels in the blood. Pink Puffers is referred to patients with Emphysema.
  • DLCO (diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide) is  NORMAL or reduced in chronic bronchitis due to impaired oxygen transfer. (Option 3)
  • Patients with chronic bronchitis are not typically obese (Option 4); they are more likely to experience weight loss due to their breathing difficulties and reduced appetite. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2133, 2180, 2185.

questions.text: Daytime sleepiness and an apnea-hypopnea index (AHI) greater than ________ are symptoms of Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA).
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: >5
 
  • Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is diagnosed if the patient has either symptoms of nocturnal breathing disturbances or daytime sleepiness, and ≥ 5 episodes of obstructive apnea or hypopnea per hour of sleep.
 
  • This is known as the apnea-hypopnea index, and is calculated as: number of episodes ÷ number of hours of sleep.
 
  • Each such episode should last for at least 10 seconds, resulting in ≥ 3% drop in oxygen saturation or a brain cortical arousal. OSA is diagnosed by overnight polysomnogram (PSG)


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2205.

questions.text: Which office-based treatment for internal hemorrhoids has the lowest recurrence rates?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Rubber band ligation (RBL)
 
  • Rubber band ligation (RBL) is the office-based treatment for internal hemorrhoids with the lowest recurrence rates.
  • RBL involves placing a rubber band around the base of the hemorrhoid, cutting off its blood supply, and causing it to shrink and fall off within a few days.
  • Injection sclerotherapy, another office-based treatment option, involves injecting a sclerosing agent into the hemorrhoid to shrink it. It may have a higher recurrence rate compared to RBL.
  • Photocoagulation and electrocoagulation use heat to destroy the hemorrhoidal tissue. They may be effective in some cases but may have higher recurrence rates compared to RBL.
* Grades of Hemorrhoids:


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1431.

questions.text: Which among the following surgeries would be performed in a case of rectal cancer which is within 5 cm from the anal verge
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  Abdominal perineal resection
 
  • Abdominoperineal resection (APR) is the surgery performed for rectal cancer within 5 cm from the anal verge.
  • Abdominoperineal resection is the complete excision of the rectum, anal canal, and sphincter apparatus.
  • This is done with the creation of a permanent colostomy. This is commonly preferred in elderly patients with distal rectal cancer with poor sphincter function.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1413.

questions.text: Which of the following is the least likely symptom of High Small Bowel Obstruction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Distension
 
  • Distension is the least likely symptom of high small bowel obstruction.
  • High small bowel obstruction refers to a blockage in the upper part of the small intestine.
  • Common symptoms of high small bowel obstruction include pain, vomiting, abdominal distension, dehydration  and obstipation.
  • Distension is more commonly associated with lower bowel obstruction, where the blockage occurs in the large intestine.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1381.

questions.text: What is the sequence of color changes in Raynaud's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: White - Blue - Red
 
  • Raynaud's syndrome occurs due to peripheral vasospasm, and it is more common in the upper extremities. It may occur due to exposure to various stimuli, including cold temperatures, tobacco, or emotional stress, and certain occupational groups, such as those who use vibrating tools, or it can be secondary to scleroderma, systemic lupus erythematosus, Sjogren's syndrome, and antiphospholipid syndrome.
  • The sequence of color changes typically starts with pallor (white) due to decreased blood flow to the extremities.
  • This is followed by cyanosis (blue) as the lack of oxygen causes the skin to turn blue.
  • Finally, as the blood flow returns, the affected areas may turn red due to reactive hyperemia, a rebound increase in blood flow.
  • Therefore, the correct sequence of color changes in Raynaud's disease is White - Blue - Red.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2778.

questions.text: Where is a Hunterian Ligature operation performed?
questions.solution:
• The Hunterian Ligature operation is a surgical procedure that involves tying off a blood vessel to control bleeding or to prevent blood flow to a specific area. This procedure is typically performed in cases of Cerebral aneurysms. 
  • The Hunterian Ligature operation is named after the famous Scottish surgeon, John Hunter, who first described the technique in the 18th century.
  • The procedure involves tying a ligature, which is a thread or suture, around the affected blood vessel to stop the flow of blood.
  • This can be done either directly on the vessel or by tying off the vessel's main branch.
In summary, the correct option for the location where the Hunterian Ligature operation is performed is option 3:Aneurysm. 

Reference: Schmalz P, Patel A, Hauck E. A Case Report on the Progressive Hunterian Ligation of an Intracranial Aneurysm by Flow Diversion: The Endovascular Selverstone Clamp. Cureus. 2022 Jan 13;14(1):e21218. doi: 10.7759/cureus.21218. PMID: 35174026; PMCID: PMC8840891.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a clinical feature of Thromboangiitis obliterans?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Absence of popliteal pulse
 
  • Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease) is a non-atherosclerotic inflammatory disease that affects small, medium-sized arteries and veins.
  • Clinical features include :
    • Raynaud's phenomenon (episodic color changes of the fingers or toes in response to cold or stress).
    • Claudication of extremities (pain or discomfort in the legs or arms during physical activity).
    • Migratory superficial thrombophlebitis (inflammation and blood clot formation in superficial veins, is also commonly seen in thromboangiitis obliterans)
  • However, the absence of a popliteal pulse is not a typical feature of thromboangiitis obliterans.
Thromboangiitis obliterans:

Which of the following cutaneous cancers does not metastasize through the lymphatics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2): Basal cell carcinoma
 
  • Basal cell carcinoma is a common type of skin cancer that arises from the basal cells in the epidermis.
  • Unlike squamous cell carcinoma, melanoma, and Kaposi's sarcoma, basal cell carcinoma tends to grow locally and rarely metastasizes.

questions.text: Which of these is least likely to have lymph node metastasis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Follicular Ca Thyroid

Anaplastic Ca Thyroid > Papillary Ca Thyroid > Medullary Ca Thyroid > Follicular Ca Thyroid.
 
  • Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid is more commonly seen in iodine-deficient areas.
  • They present as solitary thyroid nodules and are associated with a rapid increase in size. 
  • Pain is not common but can be seen if hemorrhage occurs into the nodule.
  • Metastasis is bloodborne and lymph node involvement is not seen.
  • FNAC cannot differentiate benign and malignant follicular lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following prefers a gallstones diagnosis to a Renal Calculi?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3:  Usually Radiolucent
 
  • Gallstones are typically radiolucent, meaning they do not appear clearly on X-ray imaging due to their composition, which is usually cholesterol or mixed cholesterol and pigment stones.
  • On the other hand, renal calculi are often radiopaque and can be visualized on X-ray due to their mineral composition, such as calcium oxalate or calcium phosphate.
  • Therefore, if a patient presents with a radiolucent stone, it is more likely to be a gallstone rather than a renal calculus.
  • None of the stones move with respiration.
  • Other diagnostic modalities, such as ultrasound or CT scan, are commonly used to evaluate and confirm the presence of gallstones or renal calculi, as they provide better visualization and characterization of the stones.
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1403.

questions.text: What is derived from Meckel's diverticulum?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: vitellointestinal duct
 
  • Meckel's diverticulum is a remnant of the omphalomesenteric (vitelline) duct, which connects the midgut of the developing embryo to the yolk sac during early development.
  • As the intestines elongate and rotate during fetal development, the omphalomesenteric duct normally degenerates and disappears.
  • In some cases, however, the duct fails to regress completely, leading to the persistence of Meckel's diverticulum, which is a small outpouching from the ileum (part of the small intestine).
Rule of 2 in Meckel's diverticulum:- 
  • 2% population
  • 2 inches in length
  • 2 feet from ileo-caecal valve
  • 2 types of mucosa- gastric or pancreatic



Reference: Langman’ Medical Embryology Edition 14 th page no 249

questions.text: According to the AAST scale for grading liver injuries, what grade are hepatic avulsions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Grade VI
 
  • Grade VI liver injuries are defined as hepatic avulsions, which involve complete disruption or detachment of the liver from its blood supply and surrounding structures.
  • This type of injury is highly critical and requires immediate surgical intervention. It is associated with extensive damage to the liver and significant hemorrhage.
  • Grade VI injuries are often associated with high mortality rates and necessitate complex surgical procedures to control bleeding, repair the liver, and restore vascular supply.

* AAST (American Association for the Surgery of Trauma) scale for grading liver injuries:

questions.text: Which of the following nodes receives the majority of lymph from the malignant breast?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Anterior (pectoral) nodes
 
  • The majority of lymph from the malignant breast is received by the anterior (pectoral) nodes, which are located in the axilla.
  • The anterior nodes are the first regional lymph nodes to receive lymphatic drainage from the breast.
  • They are an important site for the evaluation of lymph node involvement in breast cancer.
Other options:
  • Apical nodes primarily receive lymph drainage from the upper limb, head, and neck.
  • Parasternal (internal thoracic) nodes receive some lymph from the breast, but not the majority.
  • Supraclavicular nodes receive lymph drainage from various regions, including the upper limb, head, neck, and thorax.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 938.

questions.text: What is the average vaginal pH value during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Option 1 is correct.PH 4
  • During pregnancy, the average vaginal pH value is around 4.
  • This is considered to be slightly acidic, which helps to maintain a healthy balance of bacteria in the vagina.
  • The acidic environment is created by the production of lactic acid by lactobacilli, which are beneficial bacteria that dominate the vaginal microbiota in healthy women.
  • The acidic environment also helps to prevent the overgrowth of harmful bacteria and yeast, which can cause infections.
  • It is important to maintain a healthy vaginal pH during pregnancy to prevent complications such as preterm labor and premature rupture of membranes.

What age should the investigation for primary amenorrhea be conducted in a girl who has fully developed secondary sexual characteristics?
questions.solution:
Amenorrhea
Literally, amenorrhea means 'without menses'. By definition, amenorrhea is the absence of menstruation. Amenorrhea may be primary or secondary.

Primary amenorrhea is diagnosed if:
(1) the absence of menstruation by the age of 13 years in the absence of growth or development of secondary sex characters. or
(2) no menstruation by the age of 15 even with development of secondary sex characters.
(3) If menstruation doesn't occur after 3 years of Thelarche.

Secondary amenorrhea is the absence of menses for more than three cycle intervals or six months in females who were previously menstruating.

questions.text: Which of the following does not characterize Stein-Leventhal syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Multiple corpora lutea cyst in the ovaries.
Stein-Leventhal syndrome is a synonym for PCOS.
 
  • There are small follicles and not corpora lutea cysts
 
  • In polycystic ovary syndrome, one or both ovaries can contain multiple small, immature ovarian follicles that can appear as cysts on medical imaging.
 
  • Normally, ovarian follicles contain egg cells, which are released during ovulation. In polycystic ovary syndrome, abnormal hormone levels prevent follicles from growing and maturing to release egg cells. Instead, these immature follicles accumulate in the ovaries.
 
  • Affected women can have 12 or more of these follicles. The number of these follicles usually decreases with age.

questions.text: How much progesterone does Mirena release per day?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 20 µg

Mirena IUD and Levonorgestrel:
  • Mirena, an intrauterine device (IUD), uses synthetic progesterone called levonorgestrel to prevent pregnancy.
  • About 20 µg of levonorgestrel is released daily, effectively stopping pregnancy despite the small dose.

Mechanism:
  • Levonorgestrel in Mirena thickens cervical mucus, making it challenging for sperm to reach eggs.
  • It also thins the uterus lining, reducing chances of egg implantation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an ectopic pregnancy risk factor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Condom

Ectopic pregnancy is a pregnancy that occurs outside of the uterus. It is a serious medical condition that can be life-threatening.
Some risk factors for ectopic pregnancy include:
  • Previous ectopic pregnancy
  • Infection
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)
  • Endometriosis
  • Tubal ligation
  • Infertility treatment
  • Condoms are not a risk factor for ectopic pregnancy.

Other options:
  • OCP (Birth Control Pills): Birth control pills can lower the risk of ectopic pregnancy, but they do not entirely eliminate the possibility. The overall risk of ectopic pregnancy while on the pill is relatively low.
  • IUD (Intrauterine Device): While rare, IUDs can increase the risk of ectopic pregnancy, especially if they fail to prevent pregnancy, and fertilization occurs outside the uterus.
  • Tubal ligation can also significantly reduce the risk of ectopic pregnancy, as it involves blocking or sealing the fallopian tubes to prevent the egg from reaching the uterus, where ectopic pregnancies typically occur.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 573.

questions.text: What is the most common signs /symptom of cervical cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. vaginal bleeding

Vaginal bleeding is the most common symptom of cervical cancer.

Signs and symptoms of cervical cancer include:

1. Vaginal bleeding: This is the most common sign of cervical cancer. It may occur between periods, after sexual intercourse, or after menopause. The bleeding may be light or heavy, and it may have a foul odor.

2. Pain: Pain in the pelvis, lower back, or legs may occur if the cancer has spread to nearby tissues and organs.

3. Hematuria: Hematuria, or blood in the urine, is not a common symptom of cervical cancer. It may occur if the cancer has spread to the bladder or kidneys.

4. Vaginal discharge: Vaginal discharge that is watery, bloody, or foul-smelling may occur if the cancer has spread to nearby tissues.
Therefore, option 1, vaginal bleeding, is the correct option as it is the most common sign of cervical cancer.




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 411.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 289.

questions.text: On hysterosalpingography, an infertile woman exhibits a bilateral cornual block. Which is the most effective treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Hysteroscopic cannulation
 
  • Bilateral cornual block should be confirmed by laproscopy and hysteroscopy along with chromopertubation and the cornual block should be treated by hysteroscopic cannulation.
  • Out of the given options, hysteroscopic cannulation (option 4) is the most effective treatment for a bilateral cornual blockage. Hysteroscopic cannulation is a minimally invasive procedure in which a small catheter is passed through the cervix and into the fallopian tubes.
  • The catheter is used to clear any blockages in the tubes, allowing the eggs to travel from the ovaries to the uterus for fertilization.

Other options: 
 
  • IVF (in vitro fertilization) (option 1) is an alternative treatment option for infertility.
  • However, it bypasses the fallopian tubes altogether, so it is not effective for women with a bilateral cornual blockage. Salpingectomy (option 2) involves the surgical removal of one or both fallopian tubes. While this may be effective in cases where the tubes are severely damaged or infected, it is not the best option for a bilateral cornual blockage as it removes the chance of natural conception.
  • Salpingostomy (option 3) is a surgical procedure in which a small incision is made in the fallopian tube to remove the blockage. However, this procedure is not as effective as hysteroscopic cannulation, as it has a higher risk of scarring and re-blockage.

Therefore, the correct option is 4. Hysteroscopic Cannulation, as it is a minimally invasive and effective treatment for a bilateral cornual blockage.



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 559.

questions.text: Which age group does not exhibit Paget's disease of the breast?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Childhood 

  • Paget’s disease of the nipple, also known as Paget’s disease of the breast, is a rare condition associated with breast cancer.
  • It causes eczema-like changes to the skin of the nipple and the area of darker skin surrounding the nipple (areola).
  • t’s usually a sign of underlying breast cancer in the tissue behind the nipple.

Since the breast tissues are not well developed in childhood, this is rarely found in childhood age group.



Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 813, 852.

questions.text: What causes pyogenic granuloma of pregnancy, often known as granuloma gravidarum?
Incidence of breech presentation at term is about:
questions.solution:
Breech presentation occurs in 3–4% of term deliveries and is more common in preterm deliveries and nulliparous women.
 
  • Epidemiology of Breech presentation: Breech presentation occurs in 3% to 4% of all term pregnancies. A higher percentage of breech presentations occurs with less advanced gestational age. At 32 weeks, 7% of fetuses are breech, and 25% are breech at 28 weeks or less.
 
  • Specifically, following 1 breech delivery, the recurrence rate for the second pregnancy was nearly 10%, and for a subsequent third pregnancy, it was 27%. Some have also described prior cesarean delivery as increasing the incidence of breech presentation twofold.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions results in an enlarged size of the right atrium?
questions.solution:
In an atrial septal defect, there is left-to-right shunting of blood between the atria,(LA pressure>RA pressure) which leads to increased blood flow from left atrium into the right atrium (LA -> RA). This results in right atrial enlargement due to the volume overload.
 
  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD): Causes left to right shunt from LV to Right ventricle - leads to volume overload in the right ventricle and pulmonary circulation, not the right atrium.
  • Aortopulmonary window: Causes left-to-right shunting at the great artery level, leading to increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation
  • Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA): Also leads to left-to-right shunting at the great artery level( from Aorta into the pulmonary artery) causing volume overload in the pulmonary circulation and this increased pulmonary blood flow reaches LA/LV and hence volume overload/size increase of primarily the left atrium and left ventricle.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 409-411

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Noonan syndrome?
questions.solution:

The karyotype in Noonan syndrome is typically normal, 46,XX in females and 46,XY in males. Noonan syndrome is not caused by a chromosomal abnormality but by mutations in specific genes involved in the RAS-MAPK signaling pathway, most commonly in the PTPN11 gene



A few points to remember about NOONAN SYNDROME:-
  • Autosomal Dominant condition
  • Found in boys or girls with normal karyotype
  • Clinical Features include :-

-Short stature
-Webbed neck
-Low posterior hairline
-Congenital Heart Defects – Pulmonary stenosis, HOCM, ASD
-Delayed puberty in girls
-Cryptorchidism in boys




 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 398

questions.text: Which of the following statements about ataxia telangiectasia is incorrect?
What is a possible cause of the darkening of urine after standing?
questions.solution:
The correct Option is 1: Alkaptonuria

 

HOMOGENTISATE OXIDASE – This enzyme helps in the conversion of Homogentisic Acid to Maleylacetoacetic acid.
ALKAPTONURIA –
  • Congenial deficiency of the Homogentisate oxidase enzyme leads to the accumulation of pigment-forming homogentisic acid which accumulates in the tissues.
  • Autosomal Recessive condition
  • Benign condition
  • Bluish black coloration of connective tissue, ear cartilage, sclera, synovium deposits (Ochronosis )
  • Urine turns black on standing because of prolonged exposure to air
  • Also causes debilitating arthralgias as homogentisic acid is toxic to cartilages.
  • TREATMENT – Nitisinone; Supplementation of vitamin c

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 700,701

questions.text: Which of the following statements about phenylketonuria is false?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option (3) Excess Melanin

Phenylketonuria is characterised by the absence of enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. This results in increase in levels of phenyalanine (hence, option 2 is true) and decrease in levels of tyrosine (hence, option 1 is true) - the product of phenylalanine conversion. Lack of tyrosine causes lack of melanin since tyrosine is a precursor of melanin (not excess melanin as given in option 3). Hence, option 3 is the false statement. 
PKU is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. (hence, option 4 is correct)



PHENYLKETONURIA:
  • Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase enzyme.
  • Increase in Phenylalanine which in turn leads to increase in passage of phenylalanine through urine
  • Autosomal recessive inheritance.
  • Lack of Phenylalanine to leads to low tyrosine and hence, low thyroxine/ low melanin(which would lead to hypopigmentation) and low dopamine. 
  • Excess of phenylalanine gets converted into phenyllactate/phenylpyruvate/acetate which are toxic to brain causing clinical features like microcephaly and intellectual disability. 
  • Urine has musty odour due to excretion and presence of phenylalanine and its metabolites (phenylacetate in particular) 
  • Treatment includes - Avoid artificial sweetener aspartate; Decreased phenylalanine and Increased tyrosine in diet. 
 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 695

questions.text: What does the existence of a pulmonary plethora, a increased left atrium, and a normal aorta in a patient with a left-to-right shunt imply?

questions.text: Which of the following statements about staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Predisposed by Varicella infection
 
  • Staphylococcal TSS is associated with the toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1), which binds directly to the MHC II complex and T-cell receptors.
  • This results in a massive increase in cytokines interleukin-2 (IL-2), interferon γ, and tumor necrosis factor (TNF), leading to a cytokine storm. 
  • Staphylococcal TSS is associated with the use of a highly absorbent tampon. 
  • Non menstrual cases are seen in patients with surgical or postpartum wound infections, especially when packing of the wound occurs.
  • Varicella infection (chickenpox) is not a known risk factor for TSS.

questions.text: Which of the following trace element deficiencies and the clinical syndrome are not correctly matched?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Zinc - Night Blindness.
The other options are all correctly matched.
 
  • Zinc deficiency can cause a number of health problems, including growth retardation, impaired immune function, and diarrhea. 
  • However, night blindness is not a symptom of zinc deficiency. Night blindness is caused by a deficiency of vitamin A.
  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a condition that occurs due to zinc deficiency and presents after weaning. 
  • Fluoride deficiency can cause dental caries
  • Chromium deficiency can cause glucose intolerance, and
  • Selenium deficiency can cause cardiomyopathy.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 756.

questions.text: In which of the following - examination would reveal crossing crossing of suture lines?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2 - Subgaleal hemorrhage. 
Among the options listed, only sub-galeal hemorrhage is associated with a clinical examination revealing crossing of cranial sutures.
 
  • Subgaleal hemorrhage is a collection of blood in the subgaleal space - which is between aponeurosis of the scalp and the periosteum of the bone. It occurs as a result of ventouse deliveries due to tears of the emissary veins which connect to the dural venous sinuses. 
  • The subgaleal space is large is not limited by cranial sutures and hence, subgaleal hemorrhages can be large and can easily cross sutures.
  • Since, the subgaleal space is large - subgaleal bleed can be extremely large and profuse and can sometimes lead even to shock and DIC.





Other options

Option 1 -  Cephalhaematoma is a subperiosteal haemorrhage between the skull bone and the periosteum overlying it. Since, periosteum is tightly adherent to the skull bone - therefore, it does not cross the boundary of the skull bone and does not cross the sutures. 

Option 3 - Epidural haematoma is an intracranial haemorrhage between the skull and dura mater. It also does not cross suture lines because the dura is tightly adherent at sutures. 



Reference: DC Dutta Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 452.

questions.text: The core temperature of a child with an infection is increased (>38.5 C), and the child also exhibits tachycardia, hypotension , tachypnea, an elevated leucocyte count, and cardiovascular organ failure. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: All of the above 
 
  • The child is exhibiting symptoms of systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS), sepsis, and septic shock.
  • SIRS is a clinical syndrome characterized by two or more of the following:
    • Temperature > 38.5 °C or < 36 °C
    • Heart rate > 90 beats/minute
    • Respiratory rate > 20 breaths/minute
    • WBC >12,000/µL or < 4,000/µL or > 10% immature (band) forms
  • Sepsis: Occurs when the body's response to an infection damages its own tissues and organs.
  • Septic shock : Severe form of sepsis that results in tissue hypoperfusion and organ dysfunction.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2242, 2247.

questions.text: Which of the following sinuses is most likely to have mucoceles?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Frontal
Mucoceles are most commonly found in the frontal sinus, followed by the ethmoid sinus. Frontal sinuses are particularly prone to mucoceles due to their complex drainage anatomy and higher likelihood of obstruction. Obstruction of the sinus outflow tract leads to mucus accumulation, expansion of the sinus, and erosion of surrounding bone.

Frontal sinusitis: Frontal headache/ Office Headache with tenderness on pressing just above the medial canthus.
Maxillary Sinusitis: Frontal headache with tenderness around the maxillary bone.
Sphenoid Sinusitis: Post nasal discharge with occipital headache
Ethmoid sinusitis: Edema of eyelids and tenderness over the nasal bridge

questions.text: Which of the following meniscal tears will require a meniscectomy rather than a repair?
questions.solution:
• When a meniscal tear occurs in the outer zone of the meniscus, it is usually close to the blood supply and has a better chance of healing naturally. These tears can often be treated with conservative management, such as rest, ice, and physical therapy, or with a meniscal repair surgery if the tear is large or unstable. In meniscus outer 1/3rd is vascular and inner 2/3rd is avascular. 
  • When a meniscal tear occurs in the middle zone of the meniscus, it is less likely to heal on its own due to poor blood supply. However, a meniscal repair surgery may still be attempted if the tear is in a repairable location and the tissue quality is good.
  • When a meniscal tear occurs in the inner zone of the meniscus, it is far away from the blood supply and has a very low chance of healing naturally. In such cases, a meniscectomy, which involves removing the damaged portion of the meniscus, is usually the preferred treatment option



Reference-:https://www.physio-pedia.com/Meniscal_Lesions

questions.text: Which of the following causes a polymorphonuclear reaction and causes acute bacterial conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
The correct option is 2. Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Polymorphonuclear reaction is a type of immune response that involves the activation and migration of white blood cells called polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs) predominantly Neutrophils, to the site of infection or inflammation.
  • Acute bacterial conjunctivitis is an infection of the conjunctiva, the thin membrane that covers the white part of the eye and the inner surface of the eyelids, caused by bacteria.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not result in hemorrhagic conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Influenza virus.
 
  • Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis refers to inflammation of the conjunctiva characterized by hemorrhage or bleeding in the conjunctival blood vessels.
  • Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, also known as Apollo disease, was first described in Ghana in 1969. Two picornaviruses, enterovirus 70 and coxsackievirus A24, are the usual causative agents. Less commonly, it is caused by adenovirus type 11. 
  • Patients present with pain, watering, mild photophobia, transient blurring of vision, and lid swelling. On examination conjunctival congestion, chemosis, multiple hemorrhages in bulbar conjunctiva, follicular hyperplasia, lid edema, and preauricular lymphadenopathy.
Influenza virus (4), while it can cause conjunctivitis, is not typically associated with hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 185.

questions.text: A six-month-old infant is diagnosed with bilateral cataracts. Which of the following can be suspected by a urine test?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Galactosemia.
 
  • Galactosemia is a metabolic disorder in which the body is unable to properly metabolize galactose, a sugar found in milk and other dairy products.
  • Infants with galactosemia are unable to break down galactose into glucose, leading to its accumulation in the body.
  • Galactosemia can present with bilateral cataracts, especially in infants.
  • The presence of galactose in urine (positive Benedict's test), elevated blood galactose level, and elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level help in confirming the diagnosis.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 396.

questions.text: Which of the following has a visible soemmering ring?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Lens capsule.
 
  • Posterior capsular opacification is a common complication following uncomplicated cataract surgery.
  • It occurs due to the proliferation of lens epithelial cells that are left behind inside the capsular bag after surgery.
Clinical features:




Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 221.

questions.text: Where is Scarpa's staphyloma seen?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Myopia.
 
  • Scarpa's staphyloma or Posterior staphyloma is primarily seen in individuals with myopia, also known as nearsightedness.
  • Myopia is a refractive error in which the eye is unable to focus properly on distant objects, causing blurred vision.
  • In high myopia, the eyeball can elongate, leading to structural changes in the eye, including thinning and bulging of the posterior sclera.
  • Scarpa's staphyloma refers to the localized protrusion or bulging of the posterior sclera due to the elongation and stretching of the eyeball.
  • Common causes of ciliary staphyloma is end stage primary/secondary glaucoma and the most common cause for posterior/Scarpa’s staphyloma is pathological myopia.  



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 149, 150.

choices.text: Congested vessels cannot be moved with cotton bud

questions.text: Which of the following suggests episcleritis while distinguishing it from scleritis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Blanching of vessels with 10% phenylephrine.
 
  • Episcleritis and scleritis are both inflammatory conditions that affect the outer layers of the eye.
  • One characteristic that suggests episcleritis rather than scleritis is the ability of the congested vessels to blanch or fade upon instillation of a vasoconstrictor, such as 10% phenylephrine eye drops.
  • In episcleritis, the blood vessels are superficial and located in the episcleral layer, allowing them to blanch when vasoconstrictors are applied.
  • In contrast, scleritis involves deeper layers of the sclera, and the blood vessels are less likely to blanch with vasoconstrictors.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 212, 213.

questions.text: What is the purpose of Imbert Fick's Law Principle of Tonometry?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Applanation Tonometry.
 
  • Imbert Fick's Law is a principle in tonometry, which is the measurement of intraocular pressure (IOP).
  • Imbert Fick's Law is specifically associated with applanation tonometry, which is a common method used to measure IOP.
  • Applanation tonometry involves flattening or applanating a small area of the cornea and measuring the force required to achieve this.
  • By applying Imbert Fick's Law, the force applied and the area of applanation can be used to calculate the IOP.




Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 21st edition, Page no 108.

questions.text: What is the term of the relationship between intraocular and subarachnoid hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Terson's syndrome.
 
  • Terson's syndrome is the term used to describe the relationship between intraocular hemorrhage and subarachnoid hemorrhage.
  • Terson syndrome refers to the combination of intraocular and subarachnoid hemorrhage secondary to aneurysmal rupture, most commonly arising from the anterior communicating artery.
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage is bleeding that occurs in the space between the brain and the thin tissues that cover it (subarachnoid space).






Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 268.

questions.text: What direction is the eyeball moved in by a lacrimal gland tumor?
questions.solution:
Lacrimal gland situated in anterolateral area of orbital roof.
If any lacrimal gland tumor occurs the size of the gland increases which cause displacement of the eyeball in opposite direction that is inferno nasal direction



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1306.

questions.text: What is the most common primary intraorbital malignant neoplasm in children?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Rhabdomyosarcoma
Remember, Retinoblastoma is NOT the most common intra-orbital tumor (arising from orbit)- a very common misconception which students have. Retinoblastoma is the most common intra-ocular neoplasm (i.e arising from inside eye), but the most common intra-orbital neoplasm in children is Rhabdomyosarcoma. (Answer has been confirmed from Ophthalmology & Pediatric Oncology faculty of AIIMS, Delhi)
 
  • Most common primary intra-orbital malignant neoplasm in Children: Rhabdomyosarcoma.
Other common tumours:
  • Most common primary intra-"orbital"malignant neoplasm in children: Rhabdomyosarcoma
  • Most common primary intra-"ocular" malignant neoplasm in children: Retinoblastoma.
  • Most common primary intra-orbital malignant neoplasm in Adults: Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma
  • Most common primary intra-ocular malignant neoplasm in Adults: Malignant melanoma of Choroid
NOTE - The question is asking intra"orbital" neoplasm - not intra"ocular" - hence the answer is Rhabdomyosarcoma, not Retinoblastoma. 

Reference:
1. Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1322.
2. Rao, Ajay A et al. “A clinical update and radiologic review of pediatric orbital and ocular tumors.” Journal of oncology vol. 2013 (2013): 975908. doi:10.1155/2013/975908

questions.text: What is the origin of the cornea's stroma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Neural crest cells  
 
  • The cornea is made up of three layers: the epithelium, the stroma, and the endothelium.





Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 204,266

questions.text: Except for_____ each has a cherry red spot visible.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: None.

Cherry red spot can be seen in all the diseases given above.

Niemann Pick Disease:
  • Niemann-Pick disease is a group of inherited metabolic disorders characterized by the abnormal accumulation of lipids in cells throughout the body.
  • In Niemann-Pick disease, a cherry red patch can be observed on the retina of the eye.

GM1 gangliosidosis:
  • GM1 gangliosidosis is a rare genetic disorder that affects the CNS.
  • In GM1 gangliosidosis, a cherry red spot can be seen on the macula of the retina.

Tay-Sachs disease:
  • Tay-Sachs disease is a genetic disorder characterized by the absence of a specific enzyme, resulting in the accumulation of certain fats in the brain and nerve cells.
  • In Tay-Sachs disease, a cherry red spot can be observed on the macula of the retina.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 521.

questions.text: How much is the image magnified when using a direct ophthalmoscope?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: 15 times.
 
  • When using a direct ophthalmoscope, the image of the fundus is magnified approximately 15 times.
  • This magnification enables a closer examination of the internal structures of the eye, such as the retina, blood vessels, and optic nerve.
  • A magnification of approximately 15 times provides a clear and detailed view, aiding in the diagnosis and assessment of various eye conditions.
Direct Ophthalmoscopy:
  • The most commonly practiced method for routine fundus examination.
  • Direct ophthalmoscopy should be performed in a semi-darkroom and the patient's right eye should be examined by the right eye of the observer and the patient's left eye with the observer's left eye.




Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 115, 547.
