All of the following are indications of anticholinergics as a premedication except ?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Sedation and amnesia.
 
  • Anticholinergics, such as glycopyrrolate or atropine, are commonly used as premedication to provide certain beneficial effects during anesthesia.
  • Indications for anticholinergics include drying of airway secretions, prevention of bradycardia, and prevention of Gastric aspiration.
  • Some anticholinergics drugs like Scopolamine have mild sedative and amnestic effects, but most anticholinergics do not typically cause sedation or amnesia as they don't cross BBB. 


Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 409, 664, 849, 850.

questions.text: What is the recommended order of premedication before an elective intubation in a newborn?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Atropine > Fentanyl > Vecuronium.
 
  • Premedication in newborns undergoing intubation aims to provide adequate sedation, analgesia, and muscle relaxation.
  • Atropine is commonly administered first to reduce vagal reflexes and prevent bradycardia.
  • Fentanyl, a potent opioid analgesic, is given next to provide pain relief.
  • Finally, Vecuronium, a neuromuscular blocking agent, is administered to induce muscle relaxation and facilitate intubation.




Reference: Barrington, Kj. “Premedication for endotracheal intubation in the newborn infant.” Paediatrics & child health vol. 16,3 (2011): 159-71. doi:10.1093/pch/16.3.159

questions.text: Which of the following medicines is most likely to provide sedation similar to a normal sleep?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Dexmedetomidine
 
  • Dexmedetomidine is a selective alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used for sedation in various clinical settings.
  • It is known for its unique sedative properties, which include producing a state of "cooperative sedation" or "conscious sedation."
  • Dexmedetomidine provides sedation while allowing the patient to maintain a certain level of responsiveness and cooperation.
  • Its sedative effects are similar to the natural sleep state, as it induces a calm and relaxed state without significant respiratory depression or loss of consciousness.
  • Dexmedetomidine is commonly used in intensive care units (ICUs) and procedural settings where a controlled level of sedation is desired.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 412.

questions.text: Ketamine predominantly affects which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) NMDA
 
  • Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic medication that exerts its effects by interacting with various receptors in the brain.
  • The primary mechanism of action of ketamine involves antagonism of NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate) receptors.
  • NMDA receptors play a crucial role in the transmission and modulation of excitatory signals in the central nervous system.
  • By antagonizing NMDA receptors, ketamine inhibits the activity of glutamate, an excitatory neurotransmitter, leading to its dissociative and anesthetic effects
* [Extra Edge]: 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 400.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with propofol infusion syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Hypokalemia 
 
  • Propofol infusion syndrome is a rare but potentially serious condition that can occur with prolonged high-dose infusions of propofol, a sedative-hypnotic medication.
  • It is characterized by a constellation of symptoms, including metabolic acidosis, rhabdomyolysis, and cardiac dysfunction.
  • Risk factors- poor oxygen delivery, sepsis and cerebral injury
  • While electrolyte disturbances can occur with propofol infusion syndrome, hypokalemia is not specifically associated with this condition.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 475.

questions.text: What is the main factor that determines the potency of a local anesthetic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Lipid solubility
 
  • Lipid solubility is a critical factor in determining the potency of a local anesthetic.
  • Local anesthetics work by blocking nerve conduction, primarily by inhibiting sodium channels in the nerves.
  • To exert their effects, local anesthetics need to penetrate the lipid-rich neuronal membranes and reach the sodium channels.
  • Local anesthetics with higher lipid solubility can more readily cross the lipid membranes and reach their target sites, leading to increased potency.
  • The greater the lipid solubility of a local anesthetic, the more efficiently it can penetrate the neuronal membranes and exert its numbing effects.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 390.

questions.text: According to which law, the amount of pressure exerted by a gas in a mixture is proportionate to the percentage of gas in the mixture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Dalton's law
 
  • Dalton's law, also known as Dalton's partial pressure law, states that the total pressure exerted by a mixture of gases is equal to the sum of the partial pressures of each gas in the mixture.
  • According to Dalton's law, the partial pressure of a gas in a mixture is directly proportional to its mole fraction or percentage in the mixture.
  • In other words, the pressure exerted by a gas is determined by its concentration or abundance in the gas mixture.
  • This law is applicable to ideal gas behavior and assumes that the gases do not interact with each other.



Online Reference: 
Chandan G, Cascella M. Gas Laws and Clinical Application. [Updated 2023 Aug 28]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK546592/

Transducers receive waves by Reverse piezoelectric effect
Lead zirconate titanate (PZT) has marked piezoelectric effect

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the piezoelectric effect is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 1. Used in USG and MRI.
This is a wrong statement. Only USG uses Piezoelectric effect, NOT MRI

Piezoelectric effect is used in generation of ultrasound waves whereas MRI is based on gyromagnetic property of hydrogen atom in magnetic field. 
  • Ultrasound works on the principle of piezoelectric effect. 
  • The tip of ultrasound transducer consists of piezoelectric crystals fixed between two electrodes. 
  • These crystals are made from lead zirconium titanate.
  • A wire is attached to the probe which brings in electric current. 

The mechanism of production of ultrasound waves is as follows:
  • Electric current/voltage applied across the piezoelectric crystals causing re-arrangement of electric dipoles in the crystal which in turn produces mechanical vibration. 
  • Resultant emission of ultrasound beam from the probe which passes into the patients’ body constituting the reverse piezoelectric effect. 
  • Some of the ultrasound waves are reflected from different tissues and this reflected wave comes and hits the ultrasound probe creating a mechanical strain/vibration of the crystal which is converted into electrical energy. This is called piezoelectric effect. 
  • These impulses are further processed to form an ultrasound image on the screen by pulse-echo principle. 
Thus, both reverse piezoelectric effect and piezoelectric effect are used in diagnostic ultrasound.

 



Reference: Walter & Miller's Textbook of Radiotherapy, 7th edition, Page no 87, 88, 93, 94

questions.text: What shields MRI rooms from electromagnetic radiation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Faraday cage.
  • A Faraday cage is a conductive enclosure used to shield the inner space from electromagnetic interference. In MR imaging, this type of structure provides radiofrequency shielding to the scanning room to minimize occurrence of interference-associated imaging artifact.
  • Faraday cage is a conductive box used to shield out stray electromagnetic interference i.e. it keeps external electrical noise out and keeps generated radiofrequency signal from the MR machine within the examination room.
  • Careful shielding of the MR room is essential to prevent contamination of weak signal arising from patient from extraneous signal at the same frequency.
  • The shield must encircle the entire room-walls, floor and ceiling.



Reference: Cheng J, Bell D, Gilcrease-Garcia B, et al. Faraday cage. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 18 Sep 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-61562

questions.text: What is the minimum lead apron thickness that can be used to shield ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 1. 0.25mm

  • The use of lead aprons is a common method of radiation shielding in medical imaging procedures such as X-rays and CT scans. The thickness of the lead apron required for effective shielding depends on the energy of the radiation being used.
  • For general diagnostic X-rays, a lead apron with a thickness of 0.25 mm is typically sufficient for shielding the body parts not being imaged. This thickness is also commonly used for fluoroscopy procedures, which involve continuous X-ray imaging.
  • For higher energy radiation such as gamma rays or radiation therapy, thicker lead shielding may be required to provide adequate protection. In some cases, multiple layers of lead may be used to achieve the necessary level of shielding.
  • It is important to note that while lead aprons can provide effective shielding for the body parts not being imaged, they should not be used as a substitute for proper radiation safety practices such as minimizing exposure time and maximizing distance from the radiation source.

#Controversial
Some journals recommend 0.5 mm as the minimum thickness of lead protective gear. But Walter and Miller's Textbook of Radiotherapy states minimum thickness to be 0.25 mm. So, the better answer is 0.25 mm> 0.5 mm



Reference: Walter and Miller's Textbook of Radiotherapy, 7th edition, Page no 70.

Cheon, Bo Kyung et al. “Radiation safety: a focus on lead aprons and thyroid shields in interventional pain management.” The Korean journal of pain vol. 31,4 (2018): 244-252. doi:10.3344/kjp.2018.31.4.244. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30310549/

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about X-ray film?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Photosensitive material lies in the base.
This is a wrong statement.

Photosensitive material is present in emulsion and not base of an X-Ray film.
  • X-Ray film is a photographic film consisting of a photographically active or radiation-sensitive emulsion which is coated on both sides of a transparent sheet of plastic called base.
  • Most commonly used photosensitive material is Silver Bromide.
  • Firm attachment between emulsion and the base is achieved by use of a thin layer (substratum) of adhesive.
  • The emulsion is protected from mechanical damage by layers known as supercoating. 






Reference: Walter & Miller's Textbook of Radiotherapy, 7th edition, Page no 81, 82.

choices.text: Modern Knife most commonly uses 179 cobalt-60 beams

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the Gamma Knife?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Modern Knife uses 179 cobalt-60 beams.

Option A- It is a form of stereotactic surgery is a true statement. 
  • Utilizes computerized treatment planning software in order to locate and irradiate small targets within central nervous system with very high precision. 
  • This ensures delivery of intense radiation doses to the target area while sparing surrounding tissue.

Option B- It is a non-surgical/non-invasive procedure is a true statement. 

Option C- 
  • Modern knife uses 192-201 Co-60 sources most commonly, arranged in a hemispheric array in Leksell’s frame to deliver gamma rays. Though, some Modern knife may use 179 Cobalt sources but it is NOT the most common,
  • Used to treat neoplasms of brain as well as non-neoplastic conditions such as trigeminal neuralgia, arteriovenous malformation and epilepsy. 





Reference: Walter & Miller's Textbook of Radiotherapy, 7th edition, Page no 147.

Lunsford, L D et al. “Stereotactic radiosurgery of the brain using the first United States 201 cobalt-60 source gamma knife.” Neurosurgery vol. 24,2 (1989): 151-9. doi:10.1227/00006123-198902000-00001. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2645538/

questions.text:
After falling from the roof, a 50-year-old man arrives with acute chest discomfort, breathing problems, and crepitus.
Shown is the X-ray image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Flail chest.
 
  • Flail chest occurs when two or more contiguous ribs are fractured at two or more sites as shown in the given X-Ray. 
  • Results in paradoxical movement of the flail segment.
  • Can be either clinically occult or can lead to severe ventilation difficulties.
  • Investigation of choice is CT scan. 
  • Management- Proper oxygenation, pain management, if required surgical management


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 375.
Stanislavsky A, Hacking C, Silverstone L, et al. Flail chest. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 14 Sep 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-10820

questions.text: A 76-year-old man arrives with a history of headaches following a fall. A CT scan was conducted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Acute subdural hemorrhage.

The given NCCT scan demonstrates concavo-convex hyperdensity along left fronto-parietal convexity. This along with typical history of trivial fall and gradually worsening sensorium is diagnostic of subdural hemorrhage. 

Subdural hemorrhage:
  • Bleeding between dura and arachnoid mater secondary to rupture of bridging cortical veins. 
  • Associated with underlying brain damage. 
  • Not limited by cranial sutures. 
  • Limited by dural folds of falx cerebri, falx cerebella and tentorium. 
  • Pseudo-empty Delta sign- Acute SDH lining the wall of superior sagittal sinus making the wall of the sinus appear hyperdense while the contents look relatively hypodense resembling empty delta sign of venous sinus thrombosis. 
  • SDH in neonates and infants should raise suspicion of non-accidental injury/battered baby syndrome. 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 366, 367.

choices.text: Left heart border - Lingular segment of left upper lobe

questions.text: Which Silhouette sign is correctly matched in the following options?
questions.solution:
Correct option 1:Right Heart Border - Right Middle lobe
The Silhouette sign is a radiographic sign used to determine the location of a lesion in the lungs. It is based on the principle that when an opacity (such as a tumor or pneumonia) is in contact with the chest wall, it will obscure the border of the adjacent structure, resulting in loss of the silhouette sign.

 
  • The correct option is 1. Right Heart Border - Right Middle lobe. The right heart border is formed by the right atrium and the right ventricle, which are adjacent to the right middle lobe of the lung. Therefore, if there is an opacity in the right middle lobe, it will obscure the right heart border, resulting in loss of the silhouette sign.
  • Option 2 is incorrect because the right hemidiaphragm is adjacent to the right lower lobe, not the left lower lobe.
  • Option 3 is incorrect because the left heart border is formed by the left atrium and the left ventricle, which are adjacent to the left lower lobe, not the lingular segment of the left upper lobe.
  • Option 4 is incorrect 

Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 17-19, 40.

questions.text: Which of the following is a typical ERCP sign for pancreatic cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Double duct sign.
 


Double duct sign:
  • Presence of dilatation of the common bile and pancreatic ducts. 
  • Thumb Rule- It represents a malignant cause until proven otherwise. 
  • Common causes include-
    • Carcinoma head of pancreas

    • Distal cholangiocarcinoma

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1265.

questions.text: What is the first radiological sign of pulmonary venous hypertension seen on a chest X-ray?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Cephalization of pulmonary vascularity.
  • The first radiological sign of pulmonary venous hypertension seen on a chest X-ray is cephalization of pulmonary vascularity.
  • Cephalization refers to the redistribution of blood flow in the lungs due to increased pressure in the pulmonary veins.This can be seen on a chest X-ray as an increase in the size and prominence of the blood vessels in the upper lung fields, while the blood vessels in the lower lung fields appear less prominent.
  • Pleural effusion and alveolar pulmonary edema may be seen in more advanced stages of pulmonary venous hypertension, but they are not the first radiological signs.
  • Kerley B lines are also associated with pulmonary venous hypertension, but they are not the first radiological sign and are typically seen in the later stages of the disease. 






Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 399, 400.
